Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6232, file 510-5, part 7)
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

January 24, 1941.

Sir,

I have to advise that new grates are required for the furnace at the Fairford Improved Day School. The old grates are burnt out and new ones are required if the furnace is to operate properly. I have obtained prices from the firm who installed the furnace. Their quotation is $11.50 f.o.b. Fairford, Manitoba. The installation would be made without further cost. Will you please advise if this purchase is authorized.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
January 28, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant, you may expend an amount of $11.50 in replacing the grates in the furnace at the Fairford Day School.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J. Waite,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

The lower Fairford day school is now operating and there were 25 pupils in attendance at the time of my visit on the 17th of the month. The chimney is nearly finished, some grouting is still to be done. A piece of doucanda board 18" x 12' and a piece of 3/4" flooring 9' long are required around the chimney. Will you please grant authority to purchase this material.

This school is approximately a mile and three quarters from the Improved school and the caretaker of the Improved Day school feels that he should pay an additional $5.00 per month for the care of this school. Dear Sir:

Re: Repairs, Lower Fairford Day School

Ottawa, September 16, 1942.

Dear Sir:

It is noted that in your requisition dated June 18 for certain supplies which appear to be necessary at the above-noted school, you include the following:

1. top for kitchen stove,

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Reserves, Ottawa.

I am in receipt of a letter from Farm Instructor Pavelle of the Little Saskatchewan Reserve, in which he advises that Mr. John Strom of Hilbre, Manitoba has not received all the payment for material and labour for certain work on the Fairford Improved Day School. Vouchers were submitted to the Department, for this work, on October 27, 1943, and are as follows:

Voucher No. 474, $77.50.
Labour on soft water cistern $35.00
Material for kitchen, ceiling and walls $20.00
Labour on walls and ceiling $22.50

$77.50

No. 474 $66.45 Materials for building cistern.

According to Mr. Pavelle's letter, Mr. Strom only received a cheque for $60.45, which still leaves a balance outstanding of $83.50 due Mr. Strom.

I would be pleased if this matter could be adjusted as soon as possible, as it is very difficult to have work done on outlying reserves, and delay in payment makes it doubly difficult.

J. Weite,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
February 23, 1946.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, your voucher No. 474 for $66.45 in favour of Mr. John Strom for fees sent from the office at the Fairford School was received at this office on November 17, 1945, and cheque No. 13864 for $66.45 was issued and sent to him on November 20. This cheque has been returned to us through the bank. It is endorsed by Mr. Strom. I cannot see why he told Mr. Favell that he had only received $60.45.

Your second voucher No. N. 474 for $77.50, issued in favour of John Strom, reached this office on February 21, 1946. Cheque No. 12601 for the amount stated was issued and sent to him on February 26. This cheque has not yet been returned to the bank, but I presume he has received it by this time.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

I have authorized the work to be proceeded with and on completion voucher will be forwarded to the Department.

Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

126-5-5, February 23rd 1944.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

About a year ago the Lower Fairford Day School was repainted. The work was well done, but owing to this school being closed during week-ends from Friday night until Tuesday morning the plaster has cracked and is falling. If my belief that plaster will not stay on the walls and ceiling under the present arrangements, the school being closed over a too long weekend.

I would suggest that the walls and ceiling be lined with beaver-board, and at the same time the walls and ceiling should be insulated.

I am asking the Farm Instructor to obtain a price on labour installing the board and as soon as this is received a further report will be submitted.

April 12, 1944.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to inform the Department that the Fairford Improved day School has been cold during the even moderate weather this past winter, and no amount of firing seemed to make any appreciable difference.

During my visit to the reserve, I closed several cold air registers and made a few improvements. The school rooms still remained cold.

This school was built in 1915? It has a stone basement which possibly should be pointed, and there is an air space between the weather board and the stone work. This would consider the furnace adequate, although the damper will have to be repaired. This would have to be done by an expert. Is it possible that the building will have to be insulated and possibly all the siding renailed. The cost of this work would be considerable and I would like to have the services of an expert on matters of this nature. There is no man in the district capable of doing this work and one would have to be sent in from the City of Winnipeg.

I would be pleased if the Department would name a firm who would give an estimate on the work required at this school.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
April 19, 1944.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

I enclose copy of a letter that has just been received from Mr. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba. The letter does not give us any estimate of the probable expenditure that will be necessary and the Department would like to have some idea of this before authorizing the work. Extract from Inspector G.W. Bartlett's report on the Fairford Indian Day School visited on December 8, 1944.

Blinds are needed on the south windows.

There are washing facilities in the basement but not individual towels (or face cloths).

Water cooler with tap should be used instead of uncovered pail.

Heating system - The cold air registers are all covered up with cardboard. This of course interferes with the heating of the room as effectively as the closing up of the hot air registers. Apparently there was nobody on the place who knew anything about the operation of the heating system; and the room was cold, though the day was comparatively mild. I had no way of investigating to ascertain whether the closed-up cold registers are part of a discarded heating system or whether they are still in use and stopped from lack of understanding the operation of a system of air circulation. The teacher has no idea of the operation. An investigation by a competent party is desirable, as soon as possible.

In reporting on his inspection of the Fairford School on December 6, 1944, Inspector Bartlett writes:

"Blinds are needed on the south windows.

"Water cooler with tap should be used instead of uncovered pail.

"Heating system - The cold air registers are all covered up with cardboard. This of course interferes with the heating of the room as effectively as the closing up of the hot air registers. Apparently there was nobody on the place who knew anything about the operation of the heating system, and the room was cold, though the day was comparatively mild. I had no way of investigating to ascertain whether the stopped-up cold registers are part of a discarded heating system, or whether they are now in use and stopped from lack of understanding the operation of a system of air circulation. The teacher has no idea of the operation. An investigation by a competent party is desirable, as soon as possible."

You may purchase the blinds required for the south windows, also the quantity of towelling that you consider necessary. If you can secure a water cooler with tap you may do so, provided it can be obtained at a reasonable cost.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

On September 22, last, two estimates were forwarded through Mr. Inspector Hamilton's office, for certain repairs to the Fairford Improved Day School and the Lower Fairford Day School. The amounts of the repair work were as follows:

Fairford Improved Day School, Material $223.96, Labour $107.60.
Fairford Lower School, Material $151.99, Labour $80.00.

Authority was received for the work on the Improved School, the material being ordered through Mr. Smith of Erickdale by Mr. Chase, the Order being No. 26865. On October 14, I wrote to Mr. Favelle, Farm Instructor, advising him that Mr. Chase's estimate had been approved and that $104.00 had also been approved for labour.

In the latter part of December accounts were received here in amount of $152.00, in favour of Mr. A.J. Smith of Erickdale for material, and $60.00 in labour in favour of Mr. Homer Chase. The accounts were submitted through Mr. Favelle. I immediately wrote to Mr. Favelle asking him for the letter of authority, as I thought it might be possible that Mr. Chase had been advised direct about the repair to the Lower School from the Department at Ottawa. A copy of Mr. Favelle's reply is appended. This did not appear to be satisfactory and I arranged to meet Mr. Chase at Gypsumville on January 23.

Mr. Chase informed me that Mr. Favelle had told him to go ahead with the work on the Lower School. He claimed that he told Mr. Favelle that he did not have the authority and was doubtful about the matter. However, he thought perhaps Mr. Favelle would have some author-
ity in the matter, because he had previously told him that the $104.00 had been authorized for the labour on the Improved School.

Mr. Favelle readily admitted his mistake. He figured that the authority would be approved in time and as he had Mr. Chase on the reserve he would have the work done. There is a labour shortage in the district and there is no doubt that Mr. Chase is a very busy man and would not be able to return to do the work at the Lower school for some months. There is no doubt that the work was very necessary if the school was to open.

I beg to recommend that the accounts be paid.

You will also kindly note that Mr. Chase purchased the material from Mr. Smith of Erickdale. He has no lumber yard of his own and the prices of materials submitted were quoted by Mr. Smith.

J. Weite,
Indian Agent.
Little Saskatchewan Reserve,
Gypsumville P.O., Manitoba.

I beg to endorse herewith a list of materials required to build a lean-to to the Lower Fairford Day School. At the present time and under present conditions it seems impossible to obtain a bill of material from any lumber merchant. I would be pleased if the bill of material be checked before any purchase is made. The cost of labour is also estimated. The building (School) is approximately 26 feet long and I suggest that two rooms be built, 12 feet wide.

There has been no teacher at this school for almost two years. It is approximately 1½ miles from the Improved Day School and the walk appears to be too much for a teacher on an Indian Reserve. The fact that this school is closed is an excuse for the average Indian not to send his children to the Improved School, although in many cases he is just as close to the Improved School as the Lower School. This leads to a controversy, especially if the Indian's children attended the Lower School before it was closed. It also leads to some injustice in the administering of Family Allowance. This school should be open in justice to the Indian and in fairness in the administering of the Family Allowance as far as Indians are concerned. The school was renovated just over a year ago and is now in good condition. Wood fuel has been placed at the school for the operation of the school stove only. A list of needed furniture and approximate costs is also attached. I would suggest a cement foundation only, with a dug-out cellar. A well should also be drilled. The depth of the well at the improved school is approximately 60 feet. The lay of the land at Lower Fairford is slightly different, but I think water should be found at 100 feet. The approximate cost at this depth would be $450.00.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

The class-room and the residence at the Fairfield Improved Day School, in fact the whole building, is very hard to heat. The class-room especially. This room on a cold day requires all the heat from the furnace turned into it to make it at all bearable. This means the rest of the house is without heat except from the cook-stove. The building has had the ceiling raised immediately a few years ago. The walls cannot be insulated as every four feet down the walls the scantlings are braced across. The furnace at present in use was installed approximately twelve years ago, and was supposed to be large enough to heat the whole building. While new, it was satisfactory except on very cold or windy days. A full-time caretaker has been installed at this school. And while the heating of the building has improved, the problem is not solved. I beg to suggest the following improvement.

The class-room is 32 X 22 X 14. Kindly note the ceiling is very high and has to be taken into consideration in providing heat for this room. I beg to suggest a pipeless furnace of 12,000 to 15,000 cu. feet capacity. Heat for the class-room only. This would mean the closing of the radiators, both hot and cold into the class-room, thus allowing the present wood furnace to heat the living quarters only. I might state that the living quarters comprise a large living room, kitchen and dining-room on the ground floor with five bedrooms upstairs. The cost of a pipeless furnace would be approximately $180.00. I would recommend that a coal burner be supplied, as wood on the Fairfield Reserve is getting in short supply.
Ten tons of coal would be sufficient to fire a furnace of this type during the winter months.

The installation of an additional furnace would mean the building of a new chimney at an approximate cost $100.00. The present chimney is only large enough to carry the wood furnace and the cook stove. It is also not possible to connect the smoke pipe of a new furnace to the present chimney. The pipe would be too long and dangerous. A total figure $400.00 would buy the furnace, cost of installation and build the chimney. The purchase of fuel would be additional. The installation of the additional furnace would make it possible to again employ a part time caretaker at a salary of $25.00 per month, as against the present full time caretaker at $60.00 per month.

This school requires re-roofing. I have been trying to obtain prices on this work, without success. I think the cost would be close to $800.00, as new sheeting will be required in places, all new shingles will certainly have to be put on.

Both these jobs can only be done during the summer months, but I beg to bring them to the attention of the Department at this time, so that arrangements may be made for the expenditure.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.

Prefabricated House for Teachings at Fairford Indian Day School

The house which we have ordered is from the North American Building Company, Limited, 711 Royal Bank Building, Winnipeg, Manitoba. Please find attached a copy of the basement plan for this house which is their catalogue Number 422 R. We are advised that their 20 by 24 basement on a 9" by 7' 6" wall with a 30" by 10" footing and a 4" floor will take 30 cubic yards of concrete with 120 bags of cement at a six to one mix.

You will note on the right hand side of the plan diagram of the anchor bolt settings in the 2 by 4 sill. The bolts are placed approximately 6 ft. apart 24 inches from the outside edge of the basement wall. North American Buildings, Limited, supply the sill, anchor bolts and centre beam but nothing below the beam. If there is any further technical information required I suggest that you write directly to the North American Buildings, Limited, at the above address. If you require the 120 bags of cement please send a telegram immediately to this effect and we will request our Purchasing Agent to obtain it for you. However, if cement is obtainable locally, this letter will serve as authority for the immediate local purchase of amount required.

Encl.

Bernard F. Henry,

June 24, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: 126-5-5 (W.T.) June 20, 1947.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter relative to the purchase of a teacherage for the Fairford Day School (Lower) from the North American Building Co., Ltd., Winnipeg. This is the first intimation I have received regarding the purchase of a prefabricated house.

My understanding is, that I am to arrange for the construction of the basement for this house, which is to be 20 X 24 with a 7' 6" wall, 9" thick.

This will mean an excavation 8' deep, dimension and board material for forms to hold concrete. The purchase of 32 cubic yards of gravel and 50 lbs of 3" nails. It would appear that exact measurements would be required and as there is no one in the vicinity of the reserve capable of doing this work, it would have to be done by a contractor from the outside.

Annuity payments are to be made on the Fairford Reserve next Monday and I would be pleased if the Department could supply definite instructions regarding the excavation of the basement and if I am to go ahead with this work according to plan submitted.

During a recent visit to the Fairford Improved Day School, Mr. Marsh the present teacher, complained about the building being cold and the discomfort his family suffered during last winter. A coal furnace was installed last fall—this for heating the class room only. The house portion, which consists of eight rooms arranged downstairs and five up, is being heated at the present time by a wood furnace. It seems impossible to obtain heavy wood fuel on this reserve, as the heavy wood is badly depleted. I would suggest that a coal furnace be installed. The windows and doors are loosely fitted and considerable cold enters the house through these openings. I would suggest that all windows and doors in the building be refitted. Most of the floors are in bad shape; they are of fir, old, and badly blistered. The installing of the furnace should be done by an engineer and I would request that Mr. Connally be requested to check over the heating system in this building and furnish a report. I would also be pleased if the Agency Superintendent could be authorized to obtain the cost of refitting the windows, doors, etc.

J. Waite,
Field Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

The Lower Fairford School recently opened under Mr. Murray as teacher, is crowded with approximately thirty-nine pupils. There are still fourteen to sixteen children of school age that should attend. The ventilation is very poor and I have requested, assistant Agent Favelle to obtain prices of the installation of two ventilating windows on the north wall. Prices will also be obtained for the removal of the partition between the school proper and the two cloak rooms. This will enlarge the school approximately ten feet and later a partition lean-to could be built to the school as cloak rooms. This change will mean that the chimney will have to be removed and rebuilt at the end of the school. The cost of these changes should not be high and as soon as estimates are received the bill of cost will be forwarded to the Department for approval.

The two toilets are in poor condition and I have requested that an estimate be obtained for the building of two new ones. This cost will be forwarded to the Department for approval when received.

J. Waite,
Field Agent.

Gypsumville, P.O., Manitoba.

FAIRFORD IMPROVED INDIAN DAY SCHOOL:

This school was built on the same standard as the school we have at Pelly. It has the same living quarters and 1 classroom. A new school was built here last summer, so there are now 2 classrooms; previous to that, the dining room was used as a classroom. The

The senior room is taught by Miss Thomas and the junior room by Miss McCabe. There are 67 children on the register and on the day of my visit at the school there were 32 in the junior room and 25 in the senior room, a total of 57. The average attendance, I believe, was about 55.

Two vans are used in transporting the children to and from school, one from Lower Fairford and the other from Upper Fairford. These children are also supplied with a mid-day meal. An Indian who lives about two miles from the school acts as Janitor, keeps on fires, etc., and a girl is employed in the kitchen to do the housework, look after meals, etc. This is generally an Indian girl.

I spent half a day in the classrooms and I was favourably impressed with the work that is being done here. I consider that Miss Thomas and Miss McCabe are splendid teachers and they are certainly very much interested in their work. They keep the children clean and tidy and take an interest in their health just as much as they do in their school work. They have a pony at the school, that they drive around with, and in cases of sickness they always give all possible assistance. They have also done considerable work in advising the mothers about keeping their children clean, etc. These two ladies are now in their fourth year on the reserve.

Miss Thomas asked me if there was any such thing as an increase in salary for teachers on an Indian Reserve, as she pointed out that they were still getting the same salary as they did when they started. Miss McCabe is getting $700.00 a year and Miss Thomas, $800.00. Out of this, of course, they have to provide themselves and the girl that is in the kitchen. Miss Thomas further stated that it was not just for the sake of getting more money, but that even if they got a small increase in salary, she would feel that their work was satisfactory to the Department.

One thing I would recommend is that they be furnished with a little more furniture. These women are living an isolated life and I think we should make them as comfortable as possible. And when I see how well some of the boarding schools are furnished, I think the Department should supply this place with the bare necessities, as most of their furniture is makeshift, made out of boxes, etc. Should the Department have funds for this purpose, I can furnish a list of what is actually required. The school building as a whole is in good shape.
The Inspector comments favourably on the Improved Day School on the Fairford Reserve. The teachers, Miss Thomas and Mrs. Macdonald, seem to be doing good work, and they have a large attendance at the school. I would draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks regarding an increase in salary for these teachers, and I am of the opinion that if there is any way of granting the request it should be done.

With reference to the Inspector's remarks regarding the poorly furnished condition of the living quarters at this school, I think, myself, that we should do something to make living conditions more comfortable for these women. And for an outlay of about $200.00 we might be able to buy the necessary furniture. I do not know whether any rugs or linoleum are required or not; if so, they would be additional.
Ottawa, March 5th, 1926.

Sir:

Relative to the request made by Mr. Inspector Christianson in his report on his inspection of the Fairford Improved Indian Day School that a quantity of furniture be supplied for the use of the teachers' residence, and also to your request regarding this request as contained in your No. 205-9 of the 23rd ultimo, I beg to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding $200 in the supplying of the necessary furnishings. I shall be pleased if you will arrange for the purchase and delivery of the furnishings which you consider necessary, the cost of which should not exceed the above authorized amount. We will have funds in our next year's appropriation to cover this expenditure.

Please forward accounts in the usual manner covering the cost of the furnishings supplied.

Your obedient servant,

I just returned from the Fairford Reserve, and on checking over the buildings, I found that the new teacher's residence at Lower Fairford School was sinking in the middle causing the partition to come away from the floor about 1/2 inches. Also, there is a leak in the roof. I believe this was caused by water getting into the basement, the building not having any eavestroughs.

I have ordered eavestroughs to be put on the school at once, and also for Mr. Helgesson from Ashern to come up and repair the building before it gets any worse. The cost of this should not be very great.

I will be forwarding accounts for this at a later date, and hope my actions meet with your approval.

Rev. Sir,

I am in receipt of a number of reports upon the schools of the Northern part of Lake Winnipeg, and must say that the school educational work is not generally carried on very satisfactorily, whilst there are very great defects of a more material nature.

Pisshar River. The complaint here is that up to lately and for a year past insufficient teachers have been in charge. With the large population to be found at this point, it seems essential that a well qualified and permanent teacher should be employed.

Berens River. Here there is a fine building and good chances of a fair attendance, but since last June either through the absence of a teacher, or the presence of measles, or even when a teacher was in charge, the school has been practically closed right along. True the grant has not been paid, but little good can be effected unless the school is continually kept open.

Peylar River. At this point there appears to be the need of a new building. Unfortunately we have no funds and it will take some time before provision is made for the purpose.

In reply to your letter No 118277/1 of November 18
1910 you say that the Department would be glad to
have my views as to the desirability of making pro-
vision for the giving of a mid-day meal at the Fish-
er River Day School.

Before saying anything in reply I must call the
attention of the Department to a Report of mine on
the question of a School for the Peguis Reserve sent
to Ottawa on the 22nd inst. This has reference
to the whole situation at Fisher River and it must
be understood that anything which I may have said
there takes preference over this.

In this letter I am simply answering your
query in the letter quoted above and am just speaking
of things as they are today and as they might be
at a given place under other conditions. I am by no
means abandoning the idea of the Boarding School at
Fisher River which as I said before would do away
with Day Schools in this locality.

In speaking of a Mid-day meal the first consid-
eration is a suitable kitchen and dining room where
the meal could be prepared and eaten without distur-
bing the routine of School work.

The Kitchen should not be less than 10 x 10 in
size. The Dining Room should be 12 x 15 at least.
That is to say you want a building 12 feet broad
and 25 feet long to be divided up into kitchen
pantry and dining room.

Then you will have to consider who shall do the
cooking and whether house room must be provided for
the person who prepares the meals takes care of materials and keeps the place clean. If such a person were married and had no family possibly we might consider them in planning the new building so as to make room for them over head. That is to say again that an upstairs might be added when we were constructing the building for the accommodation of the cook who if a woman could not live alone in the place.

This then will give us a basis from which to calculate the cost of the necessary building. I write this down as likely to cost $375.00

Next comes the cost of furnishing the place providing tables, chairs, dishes, cooking utensils, cook-stove, table cloths, towels and fuel. This would cost us in the neighbourhood of $800.00

Then comes the cost of Provisions for say thirty hearty youngsters every day. The cost at the Lumber Camps of a single meal is 10 cents. The number of School days in the year is say 216. The average attendance if a meal be given might be twenty. This gives us a simple calculation like this:

\[ \text{20 Scholars at 10 cents per day equals } 2.00 \\
\$2.00 \text{ multiplied by 216 days in year equals the astonishing sum of } \$432.00 \text{ for the school days of the year} \]

Next is the salary of the cook which at the low sum of $1.00 per day is $216.00. If it be suggested that the Teacher can do this without extra salary I for one would not take such a proposition seriously. Not one in forty Teachers could or would do it.

It is likely that wood and water might be provided by the children without cost.

The wear and tear would not be great if the right sort of dishes and utensils were provided.
Now let us put these charges together:

Building $375.00
Furnishings $200.00
Provisions $432.00
Salary-Cook $216.00

Cost $1223.00 For the first year or for each succeeding year say for provisions and Cook only $648.00

The next question that comes to one is how many extra children can be drawn to the School in this way and on this point I am confident that there would be a large increase possibly so great that you would have to build a new school somewhere to take the overflow away and then add another kitchen at proportionate expense.

It would seem to me to be an immensely popular idea and every Reserve would demand similar privileges and the expense of extension on these lines would be enormous.

If we were to have two such establishments in Old Fisher River and there are children enough for that then the yearly expense there would be $1296.00 Then do the same in Peguis at each end of the Reserve and we have $2592.00 as against a Boarding School expense of 40 pupils at $72.00 or $2880.00 but the Boarding School would be an all day and every day School and twice the work could be done at nearly the same expense.

So far as I see it there is much in the proposition to commend. It is decidedly creditable to the heart of the man who suggested it. It would indeed be a boon to the children who attend school. It would no doubt popularize the Department and attract many pupils. The only question in the case is that of expense. It would be easy to make a start in the new direction but hard to tell where it would land us.

I have the honor to be
Your Obedient Servant

The Secretary

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, in duplicate, giving your views as to the desirability of giving a mid-day meal at the Fisher River school.

In reply I beg to say that you apparently have a wrong conception of the wishes of the Department in this respect. In a great many of our schools a simple lunch is now being given and in most cases prepared in the school-room by the teacher. In the experience of the Department there has never been a refusal on the part of a teacher to prepare this meal with the aid of the older girls, on the contrary most of them have taken hold of the scheme with a great deal of enthusiasm and with splendid results. The proposal is not to furnish a full meal, but rather to supplement the lunches brought by the children. Where possible beef is supplied and soup made and where this cannot be done bacon, beans, rice and tea are given along with the usual biscuit ration. It is expected that a new teacher will be secured for this school at an early date and when one is appointed this matter will be again taken up. The copy of your letter is returned herewith.

Dear Sir,

I wish to call your attention to the nature of my work in connection with the school at Fisher River.

As you are aware I came here a year ago, and during last year had in my register 76 with an average attendance of 41, thus making the Fisher River school the largest of the Indian schools and the heaviest in its demands upon the teacher.

I believe my work was satisfactory to all concerned last year, while the remuneration was only $50.00 per month. This year the enrollment is at present 82 and the prospective enrollment, by Christmas time 85. The average attendance for September was 81.

It requires that 5 different classes shall be kept going all the time in addition to something for the smallest children.

Dear Sir:-

I received yours of the 1st, #116277/1, and also Mr. Carter's report of Nov. 15th, which you enclosed, and the following is my reply.

When looking for teachers to fill vacancies at mid-summer, I had no guarantee nor assurance that the new school at Fisher River was going to be ready for occupation at an early date. It appeared to be doubtful whether it would be ready before Christmas, as the Department is probably aware, it was opened on the 15th of November. I endeavored to get a male teacher for the Senior room who would be a suitable person to look after and supervise both of the rooms, but while I had several applications, none did not appear to be one that was just suitable for that particular position. In the meantime, Mr. Carter's daughter had written me asking for the position of Junior teacher. I may say that his daughter has a professional teacher's certificate, and I have every reason to believe that she is a good teacher, having taught in other schools. She is about 25 years of age. So I accepted her application to take charge of the Senior room.

In the meantime, the Rev. Mr. Stevens' son, W.G. Stevens, who has taken up the Junior and Senior Matriculation work in Winnipeg schools, applied for the position, and not being sure just how long the Junior teacher's services were needed until we had given the matter a trial, I engaged him. It was felt that two teachers will be required between April and the summer holidays.

Now as to the trouble that has arisen, I find on enquiry that there are just two boys that have been troublesome, and they have been troublesome to other teachers and as soon as Mr. Stevens took charge he deliberately set to work to interrupt the school and defy authority. These two boys were punished with a strap about 20 inches long and a little heavier than an ordinary skate strap. It was on the hands, and with such an instrument could not be called severe and cruel. The Chief and Councilors were informed of this, and so far as they are concerned he was punished more severely if they continued as they had done.

I understand that there has been no trouble since that date, and that, at the present time, things are moving along very pleasantly. The school is well attended and none are staying away on account of the fracas.
I talked this matter over with Mr. Carter and Rev. Mr. Stevens and pointed out to them that if I took any steps whatever to remove either of the teachers on such a slight pretext, it would neither be just nor proper and it would be difficult to keep order and discipline in the future, inasmuch as the Chief and Council would consider that all they had to do was to kick up a fuss and the teacher would be dismissed.

These engagements are for the present fiscal year. I have not seen the building, but I understand that there is room for a married man to live in it. This being the case, we will endeavor to have a suitable man to take charge after June. In order to do this, a salary of at least $1000 per year will have to be provided for the same and an additional grant of $500 for the Junior teacher.

As Mr. Carter stood by his report, the school has been running smoothly and handled effectively, and good progress has been made during the past 3 or 4 years. I think we will be safe in assuming that there will be no break in this record, but that it will rather be increased on account of a better building and more hopeful signs for the future.

In the meantime, we have two smart, bright persons in charge and the school seems to be moving along nicely, and it is to be hoped we will have no further trouble.

Trusting that this explanation will be satisfactory,

Yours respectfully,

T.F./M.O.E

Dear Mr. Ferrier -

In connection with the appointment of teachers for the Fisher River School, I have just received a communication which strengthens my previous attitude that this school should be placed in charge of two qualified lady teachers, who would be entirely independent of the mission in so far as the management of the school is concerned.

Sir,

After the election of a chief and three councillors at Fisher River reserve on the 21st inst., I had a talk with these new officials of the band.

The New Chief is Joseph Everett, a very sensible and industrious man, so far as I have known him. The Councillors elected are Daniel Cochran, John Thomas Cochran and David Rundle, these with the old life councillor Henry Constable, make up the full council. The election was orderly, and the selection of the men elected, was most definite.

The chief in his remarks spoke of the school, and he desired that the school should kept open according to regulations, and in accordance with the wishes of his people. In this regard, he stated that he was sorry that the school had been closed so early this summer. He also promised to give his duties careful attention, without neglecting his personal obligations to his family. I commended him for his sensible and common sense address. He was followed by his new councillors, in the same strain of expression. They all intimated that they desired good teachers, and that they would do all to have good attendance. Mr. Ferrier was present and heard this, and their full remarks.

They asked for a team of oxen, this I promised to submit, intimating that during war times, their wants would have to be very carefully considered, as there was not much money to provide these things.

They spoke of assistance in looking after roads, I
I told them that it would not be possible to expect this for old and established roads or bridges, but if any new roads were needed, and absolutely necessary, the Department might again consider the matter, but again the war conditions made this a very difficult matter, and this would be so, for the whole period of the war.

Lieut Joseph Jones made an appeal for men to go to the front, with #2 Forestry Company, the Indians did not take this in a favorable way at first. I told them of the war, and asked them to seriously think this matter over, the work of such a company would be most useful, and they were men who could do much for the cause in using their skill to assist in this way. I might now say that some of the young men of this band have made the supreme sacrifice, and there are a number of others in the fighting line. I am hopeful that they will respond, in some measure, to the appeal made.

This covers the matters brought forward at this meeting, and the manner in which they were handled.

As to the opening and closing of the school, I have treated that in my letter, of this date, dealing with the school building, its condition, and school matters in general.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant regarding the holidays allowed during each school year.

In reply I beg to say that all Indian day schools are required to be kept open not less than two hundred days in each year, except the Roman Catholic schools, which are allowed five days extra holidays as days of obligation. It is considered that there is no call for all holidays, there is ample time in each year to teach the required number of days, and, in order to draw the full yearly salary, teachers of day schools should teach the required number of days. The Department makes no provision to allow extra leave for teachers who live at a distance from the school in which they teach to travel to and from their homes during vacations.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I am writing to you in regard to my salary as teacher here. I am going to ask you for an increase of a hundred and fifty dollars on the fixed salary of seven hundred dollars, which, plus the bonus, would bring the total salary to one thousand dollars.

My reason for doing this is the increase in the cost of living since last autumn. This is greatly augmented here by high freight rates as we are so far from the railroad. It is impossible for a married man to keep things going on the present salary plus bonus. One cannot live under a thousand dollars per year.

I honestly think my work is worth this increase. And again, living so far from town or city should make the salary more attractive than that of the ordinary school, which, however, is not the case. You will probably have noticed the increases which have been granted to the teachers in the ordinary schools. Quite recently I was offered a good school in the Province by the Dept. of Education but rather than accept I determined first to ask you about an increase in salary.

I trust you will see fit to forward this to the Indian Department with any recommendation you may see fit to add.

Respectfully yours,

Sir,

The attention of the Department has been drawn to the poor attendance of Indian children at the Fisher River Indian Day School. The average attendance as shown by the returns received during the last year is less than fifty per cent of the enrolment. There does not seem to be any reason why all the children in good health should not attend regularly. The Department has been under considerable expense in the past year in repairs and improvements at this school and good educational facilities are provided and the Indian parents should take advantage of the same and see that their children derive full benefit by regular attendance.

You will, therefore, be good enough to inform the parents that it is expected that their children of school age and in good health will attend regularly each day school is open. If, after due notice is given, any of the parents refuse or neglect to see that their children attend, steps will be taken in the case of the worst offenders to have their children sent to the Brandon Industrial School, or to a residential school of the religious denomination to which the parents belong. The Department will expect you to give your attention to the matter of attendance at this school and you will, therefore, inform the teacher a list of those children who do not attend regularly and at a later date inform the Department, when the question of placing such delinquent children in residential schools will receive consideration and you will be advised as to the steps you should take in the matter. You will, therefore, inform the parents that the Department must insist on a more regular attendance at this school and, if they neglect this warning, their children will be sent to a residential school. Be good enough to give this matter your earnest attention.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter #136-2-1 of the 24th ultimo, with reference to a request made by Chief Dan Cochrane of the Fisher River Band, for a school in the West end of Fisher River Reserve.

I have looked into this matter, and I find the Chief has not stayed within the facts. The Chief gives thirteen children of school age. As a matter of fact, there are only ten, ranging from seven to thirteen years of age. The distance the majority of these children would travel is not as great as the mileage given by the Chief. This school would come up very prominently when times are hard on this reserve to provide work for some of the men on the reserve. There is also a belief among the people on this reserve, that any money that comes from the Department grows on trees.

I have discussed this matter at different times with the missionary on Fisher River Reserve, also with the two teachers at present on the reserve, and we have always come to the conclusion that Fisher River has a first class school, at present large enough to accommodate all the children on the reserve, and with the present school accommodation and arrangements, there is no extra hardship put on the children from the West end, as there are children attending school from the East end who have as far to travel, and not nearly as good a road, among them being Chief Dan Cochrane's children. This not only applies to the Fisher River Reserve, but also to the schools on Peguis Reserve, where we have children attending regularly from a greater distance.

After taking all facts into consideration, I cannot recommend any expenditure for the erection of a new school, or the transportation of any children to the present school, as I find to erect, and equip a school would cost a greater amount than $1000.00 and that would be for a log building such as we have on Peguis, which I hope never will be built.

For transporting the children 200 teaching days at $3.00 per day, would be $600.00.

I am enclosing a list of children, with date of birth, living in the West end of the reserve.

I have the honour to be,
your obedient servant,

Indian children sing of police and friends.

R.C.M.P. check sale of liquor to Fisher River Indians.

Up at Fisher River, the Indian children have a song about the R.C.M.P. who have checked the worst type of criminal—the seller of liquor to the Indians. In a Christmas season letter, the Free Press correspondent at Fisher River tells of the training of the Treaty Indians in Canadian citizenship, mentions the fight against liquor, and sends a copy of the song, the Indian children sing.

I am sure that your readers will be interested in hearing about how the work of training our Treaty Indians in Canadian citizenship is being carried on.

Your readers have been informed from time to time during the last two years as to the efforts of the R.C.M.P. police to put down the traffic in intoxicants among the Indians about and adjacent to Lake Winnipeg. After a long, tedious fight against the vendors of intoxicants—aided by lawyers whose whole effort is to protect criminals—this to their shame—this iniquitous business has been pretty well curtailed. Friends of the Indians are glad and are thankful to the R.C.M.P. police for their good work.

We know that there are people in Canada who think we have come to the day when the R.C.M.P. should be disbanded but if they lived among Indians or on the edges of civilization—the last frontiers—they would not think so.

Recently Inspector Meads visited Fisher River and we hope he has put the lid on the liquor traffic among the Indians. When here, our school teachers Mr and Mrs W.G. Tong invited him to visit our day school. Indian Agent McGuish and Constable Curry and Rev Mr Stevens were also invited.

The school children, seventy in number, all looking very clean and happy had been taught to sing a song for the occasion.

The Mountie is a very good man,
He will help us all he can;
We will work with all our might
Helping him to enforce the right.

If we fail our bit to do,
He will never think us true,
In the promise, that we say
We will try and keep each day.

When our Agent comes this way
We often get a holiday;
For this "Thank you" we will say.
Come again some other day.

Farewell Mr Mountie, farewell, adieu,
When in Winnipeg we'll think of you,
We were a little frightened
When the Mounties first came through
But now we find them faithful friends
Who're constant, brave and true.

Teaching like this must have an effect for good on the rising generation of Indians.

The Junior school-room was very tastefully decorated for the occasion. The programme consisted of songs, recitations, dialogues and a splendid by the girls. When it is remembered that the performers were Indians, and more familiar with the Cree language than with the English, the performance was remarkable. The children were all well and tastefully dressed and all clean and neat. There was a big crowd of parents and friends present, all proud of their children and taking a keen interest in the whole performance.

FISHER RIVER CHRISTMAS TREE
Fisher River Christmas Tree was held in the United Church on Christmas Eve. There was a great crowd present, room not being found for all. The tree was a great spruce 20 ft tall and having a spread of branches 14 to 16 ft. Lines extended to both sides of the church and a great display of gifts was to be seen. Silk embroidery on deerskin or moose skin was much in evidence. Huts, mocassins, coats, etc., were very brilliant and beautiful. The school children gave a number of Christmas songs being directed by W.G. Tong.

Sir,—
Re Midday Meal — Fisher River Day School.

Replying to your letter of the 19th ultimo with reference to the above-stated matter, I beg to advise that I have done thoroughly into this matter with both Mr. and Mrs. Tong; have observed the preparation and serving of the number of occasions since the visit of Mr. Inspector Hamilton and beg to report as follows:

1. The total time spent each day in the basement kitchen and dining room by Mrs. Tong is from 9:50 a.m. until 12 noon, amounting to two hours and 10 minutes each day during which she is absent from the classroom.

2. The preparation each morning consists of cutting up meat, washing potatoes, peeling carrots, onions and turnips. In addition, food on stove has to be watched and fire in range kept going. On days during which beans, split peas, rice, etc., are used in place of fresh vegetables, preparation consists in cutting up of meat and cooking of dinner. During these days Mrs. Tong usually makes dumplings or fresh biscuits for the meal.

3. The average amount of vegetables used each day consists of 25 lbs. potatoes, 4 lbs. carrots, 6 lbs. turnips and 2 lbs. onions. Average amount of fresh meat used each day is 10 lbs.

4. After a number of trials, both Mr. and Mrs. Tong state that it is not possible to carry out the daily preparation of meal without her constant supervision. These boys and girls attending school who are over 15 years of age and girls under that age who do the work each day in the kitchen are not dependable unless Mrs. Tong is thereto watch them.

5. The meals served are the simplest possible taking into consideration what growing children need. The created appetite for vegetables and the increased consumption of them by the children has brought about a great improvement in their health. Dr. Bird has looked over the daily menus and states that there is nothing superfluous in any of the meals. Vegetables especially, from the point of view of health, are essential.

6. Regarding Biscuits, one is now served with the meal and the other given to the children at 4 p.m. When the meal was first started, Mr. Tong asked Mr. Inspector Christianson about reduction in supply of biscuits. He was informed that there would be no reduction in the supply of these and to use them as he thought fit.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, reporting on the work which is undertaken by Mrs. Tong, the assistant teacher at the Fisher River Indian Day School, in the preparation and serving of the midday lunch for the pupils.

It is considered that the time occupied by Mrs. Tong in the preparing of this lunch militates against her duties in the classroom. In order that she may devote more attention to these duties, the Department will approve of engaging the services of a woman from the reserve to prepare the midday meal, with the assistance of two of the older grade pupils. If you can obtain the services of an Indian woman who would be willing to supervise the meal, the Department will be prepared to allow her a remuneration not exceeding the sum of $12 per month. It may be that you can secure the services of a woman for the sum of $10 per month.

If this woman is engaged, you may forward certified vouchers, from time to time, for the amount of salary due her. Mrs. Tong might exercise supervision over the work, but this should not take up her time from the regular classroom duties.

We note that both yourself and Dr. Bird do not consider the meal being served to be too elaborate and that you believe any reduction in the items of diet would not be in the best interests of the pupils. It is hoped, however, that all expense for the food supplies and the preparation and serving of the meal will be kept down to the lowest possible cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir,

We, the Chief and Councillors of the Fisher River Band of Indians, on behalf of the Band duly assembled, respectfully beg to address you upon the matter of the reported dismissal of the teachers of the day School upon our Reserve, Mr. and Mrs. W.J. Tong.

These teachers have been with us since the year 1921 and are well liked by us all and are entirely satisfactory in every way.

We understand that the move for the termination of the services of these teachers was made by the Missionary here and supported by the Officials of the United Church.

We would respectfully beg to remind you that we made a treaty, of which reserve School is a part, with the Government of Canada and not with any Church, and we resent any interference in our School or any other treaty matters by any Church or Missionary.

It is through the arrogant interference of the Missionary, supported by his church that has caused all the trouble with our teachers and other Officials and many petitions have been sent to the Church for his removal but no notice has been taken of them and many of our people have left the United Church and become members of the Apostolic Church, in consequence.

Dear Sir:

Re: Fisher River Indian Day School.

As I expect to be in Ottawa soon and will have the opportunity of discussing with you personally the whole situation at Fisher River, I do not wish to go into detail in answering your very kind letter of May 26th, enclosing copy of a petition from the Chief and Councillors of the Fisher River Band regarding the removal of Mr. and Mrs. Tong. I wish merely to state that it is now three years since I raised this question personally with Mr. and Mrs. Tong and with Mr. Ferrier, who was then Superintendent of Indian Education. Re: Fisher River Indian Day School.

This is not a new problem, as the files of both the Department of Indian Affairs and the Board of Home Missions can testify. I could not help but discuss the issue in detail by correspondence, but merely to state that it is now four years since I raised with Mr. Russell Ferrier the question of a change in the teachers at Fisher River, and it is three years since I told Mr. and Mrs. Tong personally that we had to look forward to a change. There has also been some correspondence with Mr. Hamilton, the Inspector in Manitoba.

I merely want to state that on March 13th, 1933, I wrote Mr. Tong that while it was impossible to continue the employment of his wife, I would be willing to name her for one more year. These paragraphs, taken from my letter of that date, explain the attitude of the Board of Home Missions, and I feel free to state that there is no way in which Mr. Tong can continue at Fisher River after the end of June:

"As you are undoubtedly well aware, there are hundreds of United Church teachers - University graduates and others possessing the very highest professional qualifications - without employment at the present time. It is often difficult for us to explain to those who raise the issue why we should employ people who belong to another Church and who are not vitally interested in the missionary work or the Reserve of which the School should be an integral and related part. On the other hand, we cannot overlook the splendid reports which have been given concerning your work in the classroom during the years that you have served with us in our programme of Indian Education at Fisher River.

"The conclusion at which we finally arrived was that, if you desire to continue with us, we will recommend your appointment as Principal of the School for the year..."
"1933-1934, the understanding being that during that year you will make whatever plans are necessary in order to secure another mission. Beginning with the new school year we will recommend a new teacher for the Junior Room, with the necessary professional qualifications. So far, we have done nothing towards the securing of this specialist in primary and junior work, but will try to find an experienced teacher with a vital missionary purpose, who will be able to direct a certain amount of extra-curriculum activity."

The main issues, of course, are not mentioned in this correspondence, but I shall be in Ottawa before the end of next week and be glad to go over with you in detail the whole situation.

Memorandum:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

In the past, the Department has permitted the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada to select the teacher for the Fisher River Indian Day School, (Reserve No. 44 - Electoral District of Selkirk).

The Indians of this Band are practically all members of the United Church of Canada, and, for several years past, Mr. F. J. Teng has been the teacher of the school. Recently, Mr. Teng is a member of the Anglican Church, and the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada have advised the Department that he does not work in harmony with the United Church missionary on the reserve. As a result, the progress of the school is impeded.

The Board of Home Missions of the United Church therefore request that Mr. Teng's services be dispensed with, and they nominate Miss Isabel Ferris as teacher for the academic year 1934-35. Miss Ferris has the necessary qualifications and has had three years' experience in Indian work, as teacher of the Cross Lake Indian Day School.

In view of the interest that the United Church of Canada has always taken in the Fisher River Indian Day School and the cooperation which they have always given to the Department in furthering educational activities on this reserve, I consider that it is advisable to meet their wishes, as outlined above. I would therefore appreciate your concurrence in the dismissal of Mr. Teng and the appointment of Miss Ferris.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

The Department has received the resignation of Miss Esther Gaudin, teacher of the junior room at the Fisher River Indian Day School. Her resignation is effective at the close of the present month.

On the nomination of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, the Department is approving the appointment of Miss Marguerite Stevens as teacher of the junior room for the period January 1st to June 30th, 1935. MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

In further reference to my memorandum of the 17th ultimo and the 5th instant regarding the nomination by the authorities of the United Church of Canada of teachers for the Fisher River Indian Day School (Reserve No. 44 - Electoral District of Selkirk), Man., for the coming academic year, I wish to inform you that a communication has been received from D.P.S. H. W. McMillan, Deputy Superintendent General, dated Winnipeg, the 13th instant, in which he states as follows:

"I have discussed the matter of Mr. Tong's position at Fisher River with Mr. Hamilton, who speaks in the highest terms of the work that Mr. Tong has done in his school at that point. Mr. Hamilton informs me that no day school in his inspectorate has been conducted in a more satisfactory manner.

"In consideration of the above, I would think that this situation should be reviewed very carefully before we recommend to our Minister that the services of Mr. Tong be dispensed with."

In view of the above, I beg to suggest that Mr. Tong's services as senior teacher be continued until the end of the present calendar year, December 31st, 1935. You will approve that his case be placed before His Grace the Archbishop of Winnipeg, Lord, who has the nomination of teachers for the Anglican schools in Manitoba. I am aware of any vacancy at present in the Anglican schools, but it may be possible to place Mr. Tong at the beginning of the new year, and, if this arrangement could be carried out at that time, it would, no doubt, please all parties concerned.

I note that the replacement of Miss Marguerite E. Stevens, the junior teacher, is approved.

I should be pleased to have your direction regarding retaining the services of Mr. Tong as senior teacher for the balance of the present calendar year.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I have quite made up my mind that we need not expect a favorable reply from the Minister in regard to our nominations for the Fisher River School, and there seems small prospect of any change taking place before the date set for the opening of school. I am prepared—if you will recommend it—to withdraw my original nominations, consent to Mr. W. G. Tong remaining for the present, if the Department will agree to leave Miss Stevens in the Junior Room, temporarily.

The relations between Mr. Tong and Rev. F. G. Stevens and his family are so strained—and there is no other place in the community where a junior teacher can be accepted—the Stevens home—that I do not like to consider the possibility of sending a stranger there at the present time. I will await your advice before writing officially.

Thanking you for your co-operation,

I am

Yours sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

Dear Sir,

The development in the senior classes at Peguis and Fisher River Schools is such that we would need some statement of policy in regard to Junior High School. It seems to me that the somewhat simple course on General Science in Grades VII, VIII, and IX would be both useful and attractive to the pupils just at the time they are likely to think of dropping off from school. This will call for an expenditure of $5 to $10, with possibly a two dollar expenditure annually to maintain the equipment in each school where the pupils reach this grade.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter 136-7-1 of Nov 25th re the driver for the van at the Fisher River Day School.

The Indians had asked Mr. Spence, our Farming Instructor what the Department were going to do re a van or a new school. He told them that he did not know but that he understood that some consideration was being given the matter of getting the children to the school. I might add that on investigation I found that some of the Indians, whose names are on the letter, did not sign the letter submitted to you.

With regards to the hire of a van driver, the man whom offered his services for $2.00 per day can not be considered a reliable person for this job. I do not believe he would continue to run the van at that price. I am of the opinion that $3.00 per day is a fair wage for this job. You will understand that while the van is running it is a full time job for the driver and he will have practically no time to earn any other money and whoever takes this job will have to buy grain for his team which is a considerable item this year.

I might say that on the authority of your letter of Nov 17th, I hired Jas A. Murdoch to drive the van at the rate of $3.00 per day. This man had practically no means of earning a living except by trapping and he has a family of eight children to support. If the Department decide to continue the van after the new year I would recommend that the above named continue as the driver @ 3.00 providing his services continue to be satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

J. Clapke,
Indian Agent

Ottawa, April 7, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 31st ultimo, you may continue driving the children to the Fisher River School for the month of April. The driving of the children should be discontinued at the end of this month, and, during the months of May and June, the teacher should keep a statement showing the attendance during those two months of those children who have been driven to the school since last November.

When the driving of these children was first authorized, the Department understood that this would be necessary only during the winter months. To drive the children during the whole academic year involves a very considerable expenditure and is something that is not done at other Indian day schools. Would it not be possible to have the Indians whose children live at a distance from the school take turns in driving all the children to Fisher River, either in shifts any expense to the Department or at a much lower cost than we are paying at the present time? I would appreciate your discussing this suggestion with the Indians concerned and advising me before the beginning of the next academic year, on September first.

Yours truly,

THE Educational Committee of the Manitoba Game and Fish association, under the chairmanship of R. H. G. Bonnycastle, has conducted a Nature study competition among the pupils of Manitoba schools. With the approval and advice of the minister of education, Hon. Ivan Schultz, and under the guidance of Miss O. A. Anderson, the competition ran from January to May and covered such subjects as trees, birds, fish, butterflies, and other natural phenomena.

Fifty cents in prizes was subscribed by two or three members of the Game and Fish association and prizes in books on nature, animals and waterfowl were distributed. The prizes were donated by the Hudson's Bay Co., and Ducks Unlimited.

The work of conducting the competition was borne by the Manitoba Game and Fish association. The prizes were in the form of nature study books, field glasses, dictionaries and subscriptions to outdoor magazines such as Canadian Nature and Bird Life.

More than 30 schools competed, the largest number being 15. Each letter size loose-leaf note book in which drawing papers and filled exercise pages were provided, was used for sketches, colored drawings, and personal notes written up on the subject matter.

First prize was won by Fisher River Indian school, Grades 1 and 2, Koostatah, Man., teacher Miss O. Anderson. The pupils showed remarkable ability in drawing, sketching and composition. In addition, the essays are masterpieces of simple, direct writing. For instance, a wealth of accurate information is given by the anonymous author of the following essay:

"The weasel is white in winter and grayish brown in summer. It has short legs. It kills birds and animals. It will kill chickens. We trap them when they are in the time." The Indian children revealed their knowledge of nature and their interest in such matters.

Bowman school, Grades four to six, Bowman River, Man., teacher Miss T. Wilson, won second prize with an entry which was particularly rich in forest lore. The pupils showed an understanding of forest conservation principles. The art work was excellent.

Bower rural school, McCreary, Man., teacher Miss M. B. Wood, won third prize with an entry which was rich in original drawing and composition.

A special prize was awarded Maidstone school, Fisher Branch, Man., teacher Miss E. J. Smith, for an entry which placed it in a class by itself.

Four days of steady, cold rains starting May 23 caught the wren and other small birds. The mortality among these insect eaters was very high. I was in Portage la Prairie May 25 and was surprised to see a Redstart dodging about in the shrubs along the walls of Saskatchewan ave.—the main street of Portage la Prairie—between the corners of the buildings for insects.

As I write (June 3) we are into another prolonged cold rainy spell. A gale of wind is blowing and the heavy, persistent rain is slanting down from leader to leader. I am at the Danby Marshes. Yesterday Ed. Ward of Toronto told me that Hungarian Partridges had been seen near here without young. He suspects that the birds are hiding in the last prolonged cold spell.

Dr. Fred Cadham raked up a house sparrow nest in his garden at Delta on May 26 and saved the young birds from cold and hunger. He and his visitors fed it honey and water in the afternoon of May 27 and brought it back to full health and strength. The warm sunshine promised the advent of spring, but the promise was a false promise for here we are again with April weather in June.

The first sign of the arrival of Yellow-throated vireos and Wood Thrushes was heard at Portage la Prairie. I heard them singing there on June 2. A male Scarlet Tanager was heard at Selkirk, Man., on May 31, by Torrey Ward.

REPORT ON SCHOOLS OF FISHER RIVER AGENCY INSPECTED
JANUARY 17th & 21st, 1944.

Indian Improved Day School - Fisher River.

In this school we have Miss Smith-Windsor in charge of the senior room, with thirty-three enrolled. Miss MacCall in the junior room, with fourteen pupils. The attendance has been fair, but there is room for improvement. A number of the Indians have been camped with their families near the lake where they are fishing, and consequently the children could not get to school; however, most of these people have moved back now so that the attendance should be much better.

The pupils are well along in their respective grades and the work seen was well done and neatly set down. I am certain the children are making good progress.

The pupils were all well dressed; many with dresses, skirts, coats and windbreakers made from Army clothing. These were all re-modelled, and the average person would never know the material was from old Army clothes. The sewing club under the direction of Miss Smith-Windsor has done some excellent work.

The school building is badly in need of exterior painting and if at all possible this should be done during the coming summer. The front and back steps are also badly rotted and must be renewed.

The furnaces appear in good condition and the building was warm and comfortable.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

In the fall of the 30-46, information was received from Mr. William F. Ross of Kootenay P.O., District, B.C., to the effect that the Fisher River Indian Day School at Fisher River, Man., had been broken into, and a quantity of goods stolen.

I immediately patrolled per R.O. Order No. 2770 to the Fisher River District, where the teachers of the school, Misses Victoria Harkness of Shuswap District, B.C., and Miss Mildred Ross of Elm Creek, Man., were interviewed.

These teachers informed me that they had both taught at this school during the winter and spring terms of 1945, and had left the school on the 15th of April, having locked the school before leaving. They had returned to the school in the evening of the 29-46, and had found that it had been broken into, entrance having apparently been gained through a basement window at the right front of the building.

I might here state that this school consists of two class-rooms which open onto a hall in the middle. The front door of this school opens onto this hall, and the back of the hall is a door leading into the living quarters, where the teachers live. This room is used as the kitchen, and there is a stairway leading upstairs from the kitchen, and there are four bedrooms upstairs, although only three of them are in any way furnished, each of the teachers using a separate room, and one room being kept as a sitting-room or store-room. The stairway down to the basement is in the hall. There is a full basement to the building, and at the back is a room where various canned foods are kept. In the hall-way are stored what are known as "Indian biscuits", which are made by Watson's in Toronto. These biscuits are about 6 inches in diameter and half an inch thick, and are shipped in 25 lb. boxes. There were 6 boxes of these biscuits in the hall.

The teachers informed me that when they arrived at the school in the evening of the 29-46, they found that the key to the back door, which had been left in the lock on the inside of the door, was missing. Their beds upstairs had been slept in. Soup and onions had been cooked in the kitchen, traces of same being found in several tin cups. A pair of old felt socks, such as are used by most of the residents of the district during the winter, were in the fire-box of the kitchen range.

They had made a thorough check and so far as they could find out, the following had been stolen:

Dear Sir,

For the past 12 years my salary cheques have been coming to me from the Home Mission Board of the United Church of Canada.

On Apr 25th I received a letter stating cheques for both Pay Day and myself. I thought this unusual call as the Indians agent happened to be in the school at the time. I mentioned this matter to him. He informed me that a new system was in force and therefore upon receiving such information forwarded the cheques to our separate savings account. Today I am in receipt of a cheque from the Home Mission Board of the United Church of Canada for salary to end of June quarter.

July 28, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Referring to memoranda of the 5th and 10th instant, regarding the teaching services at the Fisher River Indian Day School (located in the Electoral District of Selkirk), I would say it is noted you direct that the services of Mr. W. G. Long be retained.

With reference to the last paragraph of memorandum of the 5th instant, you approved the replacement of Miss Raymondite R. Stevens, the assistant teacher. The authorities of the United Church of Canada now withdraw their original nominations, and, as Mr. Long's services are being retained, they request that Miss Stevens also be retained for a further period. The reason is that there is no place in the community where the junior teacher can be found except in the home of the missionary, who is the father of Miss Stevens.

I am therefore of the opinion that it would be in the interests of all concerned to make no change in the teaching services for the present time and that Miss Stevens be re-engaged. I submit the matter of her re-engagement for your approval.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, August 1, 1936.

Please give these teachers any assistance you can in their work at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

I understand that Miss Edythe Smith-Windsor and Miss Olive Mascall have both resigned from the above School. In their place, I beg to nominate, for the senior room, Miss Mildred Enns. We regret that we cannot get teachers with normal training but, as a matter of fact, there are, I understand, some eight hundred schools in Manitoba now being taught by untrained teachers.

Leith River July 21, 1891

To A. MacKay Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Beresford River.

Sir:

We would respectfully tell you that we need a school house here very much, and we want it built before winter. If we get the promise of assistance from the Government we can start work at once. We would like help enough to build a good frame house with shingled roof.

We would like very much an answer from you as soon as possible.

David Pundle Chief.
Harry Hustatto Councilor.
H. S. Heise Witness.

[Handwritten note:]
Request to supply Enrol.
I beg to forward letter from the Chief and Councilor of Fisher River the same, he helps to build a new school house.

In this connection I have to state that on the 15th July last I informed the band that in the current year's estimates twenty-five dollars was voted for a new floor, foundation, windows and furniture for their school house.

They stated then that they believed that it was necessary and advisable to put up a new frame building, as the old one was too much decayed, and that on account of having to use mud for plastering it could never be kept clean. They however found out on consulting

before stated a new school house is
very much needed, as the old one is
dangerous to stay in.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Omnacbay,
