SPECIFICATION OF SCHOOL HOUSES

IN CONNECTION WITH GENERAL PLANS FOR INDIAN RESERVES.

Dimensions
To be one story (28 x 20) twenty-eight by twenty feet, ten feet high to top of wall plates from the floor and (14' 6") from floor to the highest point of ceiling. See drawing.

Foundation
Dig a trench the full size of the building and porch two feet deep and two feet wide and carefully hard lay a dry wall to the height of the ground, then upon this dry wall build with fair sized building stones a mason wall, with good well tempered mortar, (18") eighteen inches in thickness and one foot deep well bonded, with perfectly even surface ready to receive the outside sills of the building and porch, and to receive the centre sill build three piers in the same manner as the walls 18" inches square, all the walls and piers to have the earth well rammed on each side of them when the mason parts are dry, and to be embanked up to the sills on both sides.

Foundation A. comes in here.

Sills and Joists
Place upon a bed of mortar the foundations, walls, and piers, sills (8" x 6") eight by six inches all around the main building and porch and also the centre longitudi-

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6233, file 511-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
dinal sill, the whole to be properly halved at the corners and dovetailed into each other where necessary, and all thoroughly spiked or pinned together with elm pins.

Upon the sills place the joists 8" x 2" two feet apart centres, well nailed to the sills and having one tier of herringbone bridging of 2" X 3" staff well nailed.

Studding

The studding to be of scantling of 2" x 4" stuff double at the corners, and window and door jambs, well braced with two rows of braces and set 16" centres ready for lathing or sheeting, lower tier of braces to be 3 1/2 feet from floor.

Roofing

The roof or wall plates are to be 2" x 4" doubled of long lengths with at least 2 feet scarf well spiked together and to the studding. The rafters to be 2" x 6" properly notched to fit the wall plates and well spiked thereto, having diagonal collars as shown on drawings to act as ceiling joists, the diagonal collars where they cross each other are to be let into each other with a half inch box taken out of each timber, the whole of the joints being well spiked together. Rafters to be placed 2 feet centres end to overrun the roof as shown on drawings. Upon the rafters nail good inch boards closely laid together having a covering of tarred felt paper upon which nail first class shingles set 5 inches to the weather, with weather boards 5 inches wide surmounted with 3 inch circular roll. Finish the roof.

(2)
with a pinnacle as shown on drawings to school and porch as also large boards and cornices. The rafters and collar beams to be to porch to be 2" X 4" stuff collar beams 9 inches above fan light.

Sheeting

The outside of walls to be covered with best clapboards having under them a good layer of felt paper tacked carefully lapped at the joints.

Sheet the whole inside of the building and porch with tarred paper well lapped upon which put on diagonally 7/8 inch V jointed dry sheeting free from black or loose knots, shakes, or gum seams.

Plastering & Wainscoating

In the event of plaster being used instead of V jointed sheeting then the inside of the walls of the school shall be lathed and receive 2 coats of plaster, one coat of plaster being first put on, then the wainscoating to the height of 3 1/2 feet from the flooring surmounted with a 2" inch cap and the facings to the windows and door jams to be put on, then the second coat to be put on, the wainscoating to be of narrow width of V jointed stuff put upright; finished at the floor with one inch by one inch strip as shown; the ceiling joists or collar beams of the rafters to be covered with tarred paper, then to be battened at 16 centres and lath and plastered two coats. To plaster to be made with clean water, good sharp sand and stone lime well rendered and mixed with a due proportion of cow's hair, the whole to be run a week before using.

(3)
Angle head and plaster the chimney breasts as shown in sketch.

Flooring
Floor the school and porch with 1 1/2 tongued and grooved good flooring, not more than 6 inches in width closely laid and blind nailed. The flooring not to have any lack of loose knots or gum seams.

Platform
A platform to be made on the floor of the school where shown on drawings to have joists 2" x 6" and covered with 1 1/2 flooring, with nosing, and neatly made.

Doors and Windows
Provide and hang with 3 - 4" butts two four paneled doors 2 inches thick, seven feet high, and 3 feet 9 inches wide, having rebated frames 2 1/2 inches thick. Fix and provide best 6" American locks to each door with two keys and suitable furniture. The doors to open outwards.

Provide and fix seven English casings 1 3/8 inches thick of best stuff to receive 15" X 28" glass prime, bed, point, and back putty all the glass, supplying all stops and fastenings.

Steps
Provide and fix front door steps as shown on drawings, firmly and well made, and resting on sunk cedar or teakwood posts, having 2 inch covering with nosing.

Chimney
Build with heat burnt brick a chimney and stack as shown on drawings, starting support 7 1/2 feet from the floor, firmly frame into two 4" X 4" studs placed there-

(4)
for the purpose and bolt concrete diagonal braces and build thereupon flat frame made as shown on drawings, covered with 3" inch plank, the chimney where passing through the frame for further support between collar beams. Well purge the flue throughout which is to be 8" X 8" full, place pipe hole as shown on drawings with rings and stopper. The stack to be finished as shown. Fix chimney flashings.

Painting

Knot, prime, stop and paint with two coats work including priming all the inside wood work except the floors with Sherwin and Williams paint. The outside of building to be painted with two coats of paint made with new linseed oil and good white lead properly mixed with such other colours as the officer in charge of the work shall choose, also knot and stop where necessary. Pix and paint with three good coats the black board where shown on drawings.

Facings etc.

The facings outside, to the door and windows to be plain, and as shown on drawings. The sills of the windows and doors to be of lumber properly threaded and weathered. The inside architraves to be 4" X 1" G moulding to surround as finish of window and doors.

Barge boards as shown on front elevation to school and porch to be fitted with pinnacles, a plain barge board will be put to the rear gable for finish, a hatchway (2" X 2") two feet square to be placed in ceiling.
for access to the attic, and two rough boards will be nailed on collar beams to pass from one end of attic to the other. The trap to the hatchway to be attached to frame with 2 - 3 inch butts and admit of being easily opened and shut to act as ventilator.

Clothes Hooks
Supply and fix 50 strong double clothes hooks on battens 1 1/4" X 5" well spiked to the studs of the porch and school, 15 to be put in the porch and 35 to be put in the schoolroom, all 5 feet from the floor.

Seats
Provide 21 double seats with desks, 6 of 22 inch high, 5 of 23 inch high, 5 of 24 inch high, and 6 of 26 inch high.

Supply a good table with drawer and lock and key, table 2' 8" in height and 2 1/2 X 3 1/2 top surface, and three good plain chairs.

General
The whole of the work is to be executed in a workmanlike manner. The materials used for the construction to be good in all respects, and to be put together in a thorough manner.

No extras are allowed unless permitted in writing by the officer in charge of the work and presented to by the Department. The contractor is to supply all plant and materials for construction and carrying on the building and to its termination.

Referring to Department letter No. 136/2 of the 6th inst., stating that a request had been received from Reverend T. Perrier to have a well dug at the Fisher River Indian Day School, and that Mr. Agent Carter has been requested to furnish an estimate of the cost of having the work done, which estimate is submitted in your letter; when I received your letter, it seemed rather strange to me that we should be asked to have wells dug at the three schools where they were situated on the banks of a running river, and knowing the Indians state that they will not use well water if they can get water from a stream or river, I thought it well to investigate the matter. When Mr. Christianson was on the Fisher River Agency investigating other matters, I asked him to go into this matter of water supply at the schools, and ascertain how they had been getting water in the past, and the necessity for digging wells.

Mr. Christianson tells me the three schools are situated on the banks of the Fisher River, that the stream is rapid and runs over rocks and sand, and that he took samples and had them examined by the Bacteriological Branch of the Provincial Board of Health of Winnipeg, who state that it contains bacterial dusted from forage and is not injurious for drinking. Inspector Bunnin reporting on this matter states that the water can be classed as a good, healthy water. My own opinion is that if the Department were to sink wells at this place they would never be used, and I think the Department can figure on a saving here of between $1000 and $5000.

Yours very truly,

D.C. Scott, Esq.,

OTTAWA, June 7th, 1921.

Sir,

In further reference to your letter of April 22nd last, and previous correspondence regarding the drilling of three wells at the schools at Fisher River and on the Peguis Reserve, I beg to state that Mr. Commissioner Graham states that he has had an investigation made into the matter by Mr. Inspector Christianson.

Mr. Christianson states that the schools are situated on the banks of the Fisher River, that the stream is rapid and runs over rocks and gravel, and that he took samples and had them examined by the Bacteriological Branch of the Provincial Board of Health of Winnipeg, who stated that it contains bacteria derived from forage and is not injurious for drinking purposes, also that the water can be classed as good healthy water.

The Commissioner is of the opinion that if the Department were to sink wells they would never be used, and it would cost anywhere from $1,000 to $3,000 to sink these wells.

It is considered that the water from the river is satisfactory and the Department cannot therefore undertake to have the wells drilled at these schools.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

T. H. Carter, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Halfway P.O., Man.
OTTAWA, June 7th, 1921.

Sir,

I am directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, regarding the request of the Reverend Mr. Perrier to have wells dug at the Fisher River and Peguis Indian Day Schools.

In reply, I beg to say that in view of the report furnished by you regarding this matter, that as these schools are situated on the bank of the Fisher River, and that the water of the river is not injurious for drinking purposes, the Department will not authorize the drilling of those wells. Mr. Agent Carter is being informed accordingly.

It is considered that these schools can very well obtain the water they require from the river.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir,

I have to report to you the condition of the basement wall under the Fisher River Indian School.

The west wall is cracked the full length of the building about 15 inches below the ground line, the portion of the basement wall below the ground is leaning in, the portion above is leaning out. The South wall starting at the South West corner is cracked about the same distance from the top and extending about half way across the basement wall, this wall is also dividing from top to bottom one half projecting in, the other half projecting out. Not being a building expert or an architect I am not able to say why this has happened, but venture the statement that it is caused from three causes. First poor material used in construction, poor workmanship and thirdly the ground expanding and has the frost went down into the ground the wall was gradually pushed into the basement. As a precautionary measure I have engaged a builder to come and living outside the reserve and reinforce the South and West wall with square bridge timbers to prevent the collapse of the building and I would recommend that a competent person be sent to Fisher River School at an early date to examine the whole foundation and furnish estimates of the material required for permanent repairs, in order to have the material delivered there on the ground before the 1st of March, as the gravel will have to be teamed from the shores of Lake Winnipeg a distance of 2½ Miles, also the cement will have to be teamed from Hodgson during the winter months.

I have the honour to be,
your obedient servant,

Sir,

I again wish to refer to the basement under the Fisher River Day School, of which I wrote to you on Dec 15, and your letter 136-2-5 of the 10th inst in reply.

I now wish to advise that I have examined the foundation under this building very thoroughly, and as far as my knowledge of building goes, I would say that the whole of this foundation needs to be taken out and reconstructed. I have also looked up a portion of the cement basement floor, and find that the present foundation is built on mud, which there is a thickness of about seventeen inches, under that is hardpan, very unable, after my examination further owing to water coming into the hole, that I found in the floor; but by testing with a sharp pick, I do not think it is more than a few inches to the rock; this I cannot state definitely. This test satisfied me that before a new wall is put in, some under drainage will be required to be provided for.

While in Fisher River I took the opportunity of visiting the Lake Shore where the gravel will be procured, this is a high grade washed gravel; but hard to get at. I also interviewed a man who has been quoted for prices for gravel delivered at the school building, at so much per cubic yard. The only bid I received which I would consider was from Joe Williams on at three dollars and fifty cents per yard. The greatest difficulty in accepting a price for gravel, is they have not got the horse power, to with any degree of certainty deliver the gravel by the break up of sleighing. During the Spring and Summer months teaming over this road would be an impossibility.

In your letter 136-2-5 of the 10th inst you did not state the thickness of the wall required. The size of the building is seventy feet by thirty two inside measurement, with two dividing walls thirty two feet long. I do not know if these walls would have to be removed, or if they could be undermined, in places, and supported, to build under.

The floor space will be thirty two by seventy feet, and the thickness is not stated in your former letter.

Please inform me by night letter, or otherwise the amount of material, that tenders should be asked for.

The cement upon arrival will be stored in the old school house, which is perfectly watertight. I have had the entire building supported with tamarack bridge timbers, this is a precautionary measure, as each visit I make to this building, the foundation is cracking in new places.

I have the honour to be,
your obedient servant,

M. McCuish
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 23rd inst., with further reference to the rebuilding of the basement under Fisher River Day School, I beg to say that the outside foundation walls should be rebuilt 13" thick, and the floor laid 6" thick of concrete, finished with 1" of cement, in the proportion of two of sand and one of cement, trowelled to a smooth surface.

With reference to the two interior supporting walls, it might be more economical if these have to be rebuilt, to build in a 6 x 12 wood beam supported on wooden posts, spaced approximately 10' apart. If this style of construction is used, it will be necessary to build a suitable concrete footing under each of the posts in order to avoid any settlement. The following is an approximate list of materials required:

**OUTSIDE WALLS:** (13" thick) 60 cubic yards of gravel; and 75 barrels of cement.

**FLOOR:** (6" thick) 30 cubic yards of gravel; and 37 barrels of cement.

If two inside supporting walls are rebuilt of concrete 12" thick, the following materials will be required: 15 cubic yards of gravel, and 9 barrels of cement.

Every effort should be made to have these materials delivered before the spring in order that the foundation of this school may be put in a safe and satisfactory condition.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I understand that the Department are preparing to put a new foundation under the Fisher River Day School. This building is a good building but the foundation is wrecked. The plan seems to be to just dig out, take out the present walls and floor of the basement and rebuild the same. I have been informed that the rock formation is not far below the present depth. The foundation should be on the stone or the footings must be below the frost line. The whole of the basement should be well drained with tile out to the river bank. To do this you will require about 700 sacks of cement and 125 yards of gravel. This would give a mixture of about one to five, which would be quite strong enough if the gravel is clean and the cement is fresh.

I am simply offering this as a bit of information.

When this is being done it would be well to have the connection from the farm air pipes to each class-room enlarged. There is a 20" pipe from the furnace to the floor of the class-room and from there up to the grate the passage is in a pipe in a space made by a 2 x 4 scantling with a 14 or 16" centre. The grate is large enough to accommodate the 20" pipe. This can easily be done by an extension in the cloak-rooms and leave the wall of the class-room in each case untouched. These funnels should have been removed instead of putting a stove in each class-room.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

Having examined the furnace in Fisher River Day School I have come to the conclusion that the present state of the basement wall is largely due to the faulty installation of the furnace and I would recommend reconstructing the basement that the present cress walls be substituted by pillars in order to let the hot air circulate through the play room in the basement. The furnace at present in use is too small. The firebox will not hold fuel enough to keep fire all night. The consequence is the furnace has to be fired to full capacity, which is very wasteful on fuel. The only two cold air pipes on the furnace get their cold air from outside. A few feet from the outside intake is a cold air register in the hall. Much of the cold air taken from outside enters the building through this register. This pipe from outside should be greatly reduced in size and the size of the flue increased. This would insure a good circulation, and if the present pipe from the outside was reduced to 10 inches, it would give plenty of cold air from the outside. In addition to the two cold air pipes and the new 10 inch fresh air pipe, two 22" cold air pipes are required to make up the difference in the cold air supply to force a proper circulation, as it is absolutely necessary to take the cold air out of these rooms before you can get a proper circulation. The class room hot air pipes are diminished in size from the elbow below the floor to about 6 ft. above the floor. This should be done away with, and registers put in the floor. The register now in use in the wall would do fine used in the floor. The furnace fireplace is cracked, which lets the smoke circulate through the building. To what extent I could not say as there was a good fire in the furnace when I examined it. If this furnace was properly installed, with the aid of the two box stoves new in use, it should heat the entire building. The water pipe in this furnace should be raised, as it does not evaporate half enough water.

Installing a larger furnace would be most advisable. All the alterations and additions of pipes are necessary. The best furnace not installed properly would be a failure, under any conditions. For doing this job, which consists of taking down the furnace, putting it in the building, putting it up again, putting in 1.10" fresh air pipe and damper outside, and 2.22" cold air pipes and registers in class rooms. Closing up cold air pipe and fitting same in first floor. Increasing one pipe to its proper size. Altering all hot air pipes in class rooms, and lengthening all hot and cold air pipes will cost $75 dollars. This price does not include any repair to the furnace itself. I would recommend that if the same furnace is used that a galvanized casing, and asbestos and tin lined around the furnace instead of brick. This could be done at a slight increase in cost.

The best price I am able to get on a furnace larger than the one in use, has a capacity of 75,000 cu ft. at a cost of $675 set up plus 4% sale tax. A furnace of this size would require 2350 bricks. Bricks and brickwork extra.

Yours truly,

(Signed) D. Seebach.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo, enclosing copy of a communication which you received from Mr. D. Seebach, regarding the repairs and alterations required to the present furnace and heating system at the Fisher River Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say it is considered that, if the existing furnace is repaired, as recommended by Mr. Seebach, and the alterations made in the flue and pipes, the deficiency in the present heating system would be overcome. The Department will approve of having this work done in accordance with the report submitted by Mr. Seebach. It will, however, be necessary, if possible, to obtain prices from several persons competent to do the work, and the contract should be given to the one quoting the lowest price. All labour and material required to complete the work should be supplied by the person to whom the contract is given. As you have no doubt, a copy of the report prepared by Mr. Seebach, you will be good enough to see that the work is performed in accordance therewith, and that tenders are called accordingly. It is hoped that when the above recommendations have been carried out, there will be no further trouble in keeping the school in a comfortable condition. When the work has been completed, you will please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, together with the tenders received.

Specifications:

To secure up the present building in such manner as to carry out the following work without damaging the building:
Take down and clear away present basement walls including two basement-stairways.
Build masonry forms for, and construct concrete walls 12" thick to replace present stonework.
Take up present furnace room floor and excavate 4" lower, filling in with broken stone or gravel. Lay new concrete floor and finish with 6" x 12" mixture steel trowel finish.
Make good full width inside of basement, 12" wide (Present wall is 2" thick and proposed new wall will be 12" thick, leaving strip 12" wide all round floor to be made good.)
Excavate for and lay weeper drains all round building, outside foundation. Cover same full width of trench with rubble stone to within 6" of surface.
Put in two main drains beneath furnace room floor. (re. connecting these drains, see footnote.)
Make good baseboard and any other cutting that may be required to pour concrete.
Cut away over three doors in concrete partitions and make same good.
Make good present defects in floor and chimney breasts in basement.
Raise grade all round building 12" higher, sloping to 12" O' wide.
Refix two sheds over basement steps.
Clear out of basement all builders rubbish and leave brush cleaned.
Clear away all builders rubbish from school yard.

I agree to carry out the above work according to above specifications, completing same in a workmanlike manner for the sum of $2125.00. (two thousand one hundred twenty five 00/100 dollars.)

This price is for labor only. The Department of Indian Affairs to pay insurance under The Workmans Compensation Act, and deduct 2% from the amount of this contract price to cover same.

Note: Re. weeper drains and rubble filling. It is essential that this should be done, as damage to present building has been caused, not by poor foundations, but by water and expansion by frost bulging in basement walls. Let is saturated by water from muskeg to the south.

The weepers should drain into cess pit in basement, and cess pit be connected to main drain to River bank.

Whether or not this main drain is already in existence or condition of same if there, I am unable to ascertain without excavating; therefore cess pit and drain to river are not included in above contract, but can be done under new contract or day work when job is opened up.

Payments on progress of the work to be made fortnightly, to the extent of 75% of work completed, on verification by the Department's representative.

Dear Sir:

On examination of this plant we find that the fire pot of furnace is badly cracked and will need replacing, as the smoke is now allowed to enter the rooms through the heating ducts.

The hot air pipes leading from the furnace to the rooms are 22" or 24" in diameter and at the floor lever they are reduced to 6" x 24" ducts which run up between the studding and discharge into the rooms. This cuts down the capacity and will not give service.

The furnace is too small to handle the building; In this country we rate all furnaces at 60% of the given rating, but if the piping was enlarged and the cold air pipes changed so that the cold air could be taken from the rooms instead of from the outside when the building is unoccupied, the present furnace by forcing could be made to heat the class rooms in coldest weather but it would be necessary to store in the basement to heat it.

We would suggest the installation of two furnaces one for either side, which arrangement would handle the heating of the basement.

We would like to hear from you in regard to this matter and if possible receive your instructions to proceed with the work of
Making such changes as you may suggest, which we would be pleased to do either under contract or on percentage.

Yours very respectfully

Also doors on sub-voucher #5. The old doors in this basement had been made useless by being whittled down to make them fit owing to the settlement of the building.

All items shown on sub-vouchers #6 to #15 are for freighting equipment, new coal chute and other incidental expenses.

Wyatt & Ireland made a satisfactory job of this work. The best of material was used throughout and I am satisfied it would pass the most exacting inspectors.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MISS ANNIE T. BRANDON TRAVELLING NURSE, ON HER VISIT TO THE FISHER RIVER RESERVE IN JANUARY, 1924.

The noon day lunch is a rather poor one and a number of these children depend upon their two biscuits for this meal. I might mention that the supply ran short and was exhausted by the end of the month of November. Last year they were short for ten weeks and I spoke to the Agent who borrowed enough from the North School, but this would last only ten days with the attendance good. I make note of this circumstance only on account of this being a rather hard year and from now for some little time there will be scarce. I should like to see even a hot drink served at noon time as many walk and run over two miles to school and are on time and attend regularly. A good lunch would mean so much to these pupils, nearly all of whom the Medical officer states are predisposed to T.B. Mrs. Tong takes the girls into the kitchen and have them assist her in other domestic duties and instructs them well. Permit me to recommend that on this account I feel that it would be a workable scheme to give a lunch to all pupils and would beg to make such a recommendation. There are many big teen age girls and boys in attendance to do the duties.

I took the liberty of drawing the attention of your Agent to the heating plant, which does not seem to be a very safe one. A new chimney was built, but feel convinced that some dampers are required, to distribute heat and might say that otherwise I believe the school to be in good condition.
Ottawa, February 28th, 1925.

Sir:

Miss Brandon, Travelling Nurse, in a report on her visit to the Fisher River Agency recommends that, as the noonday lunch brought by the pupils is a rather poor one, a hot drink be provided for them at noon, if Mrs. Toner will take the assignment of the older girls, prepare a hot drink or serve soup. You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a sufficient amount of cocoa or supplies for the serving of a hot drink or soup to the pupils until the end of April, next. You may also supply a small quantity of sugar, pearl barley and rice for the soup. Should any utensils be required to prepare and serve a lunch, you may also purchase and supply the utensils absolutely necessary. You should take this matter up with Mrs. Toner, and if she will arrange to serve a hot drink or soup, you may purchase the supplies required as above mentioned. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred for the purpose. It is presumed that there are biscuits on hand which could also be served.

Miss Brandon reports that she drew your attention to the heating plant which she states did not seem to her to be quite safe. She states that dampers are required in the new chimney to distribute the heat evenly. You may enquire into this matter and see that the proper changes and alterations are made to overcome any danger and to evenly distribute the heat in the building. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering any outlay in making any changes in the present heating arrangements.

On the morning of June 5th I left Winnipeg for Hodgson, Manitoba. I had intended to take Mrs. Murdoch with me but owing to her illness at this time I thought it better not to do so. We arrived in Hodgson by 6 o'clock in the evening. Mr. Stevens, Missionary and myself Friday evening. Mr. McCuish, Indian Agent Fisher River came out to meet us. He managed to get as far as Hodgson with his Ford car. We spent a very pleasant evening there at the home of Mr. McCuish and after careful consideration Mr. McCuish decided that it would be best to start the clinic at Fisher River. We thought it would be a good idea to have as many of the children as possible out on Lake Winnipeg fishing and would not have an opportunity to receive any dental attention should they require it.

Accordingly Rev. Stevens and myself drove down to Fisher River Saturday June 6th while an Indian with his team came along bringing the dental equipment, personal baggage, etc. From Hodgson to Fisher River, I should judge, is nearly thirty miles. This would be too far for ordinary roads but excepting the few miles between the Halfway and Hodgson stations the roads were inscrutable. On several occasions our horses went down and it was a struggle to get them out. This was before the very heavy rains which started on the Sunday after our arrival and continued almost steadily for about eight or nine days.

After examining all buildings close to the school I accepted Mr. Stevens' kind offer of the dispensary of the Mission as an operating room in which we could attend to the cases. Tuesday after checking over the school I found 91% with defective teeth. This gave us nearly one hundred children under the ages of eighteen who required dental attention.

Monday I set up my chair and equipment and by Tuesday night the clinic had started. The children came very willingly thanks to the cooperation of Mr. and Mrs. Long the resident teachers at Fisher River.

Right here is a good place to give a slight description of the conditions under which the clinic was conducted. The Mission and school are situated on four acres of clearing which is higher than the surrounding country. Both the school and the Mission on the banks of the Fisher River are about four miles inland from the mouth of the river at Fisher Bay. The buildings are fine and substantial—buildings are log and all well finished inside so that both missionary and teacher have comfortable living quarters. The buildings extend as far up as halfway down to the lowlands along the Bay shore. It is indeed a pretty place in summer and a fine place for mosquitoes. Crossing the river in front of the school in a log foot bridge used by the Indian children when going to and from their day school.

Unfortunately directly the clinic started on the Tuesday noon came the rain so that practically all the children went to bed. This would have made them more inclined to have their trouble after extractions. Indeed in several cases I postponed treatment until another day when I thought it might be dry. Besides the children we had several adults wanting extractions and as they had toothache I could not very well turn them down, in spite of the fact that our clinic was really a children's clinic. In the past Rev. Stevens has had to do a lot of extracting because very often the roads are too bad for the doctor to get down, and when the doctor did happen to be there the chances were that the teeth did not ache and so the patient did not show up. The Indians like a lot of other people do not believe in showing a tooth to a dentist unless it is aching.

During my stay in Fisher River it rained nearly every day. The river rose and on the fifth day of my visit the children's foot bridge was impassable. The day before the bridge went the Indian Agent Mr. McCuish who was down to pay out treaty money had a narrow escape from...
being drowned when his buggy upset in midriver and he was thrown put
in water nearly up to his shoulders with a very rapid current. As
Mr. McQuish has had paralysis he is unable to swim and had he been
taken off his feet a rescue would have been difficult indeed in such
a strong current. As it was he lost his blankets and everything in
the rig. The treaty money was being carried over the foot bridge or
it would have gone too.

Against all odds, rain and high water, I was kept more than
busy during my stay in Fisher River. A test was made of the dental
work to see what the cost of a plate would be. While in Fisher River
I made up two plates for an Indian woman who had the extractions com-
pleted over a year ago. I figured the cost of material approximately
five dollars a plate. Of course, this is not the most expensive but
is something that I think would do for the majority of treaty cases.
For the children some two hundred fillings were completed and about the
same number of extractions for children and adults. Some forty children
received treatment and there are twice as many more to receive treatment
at some future date if arrangements can be made.

I had intended to put a clinic on in Dallas on the way back but
owing to the impassable condition of the roads I did not see how the
children or the white settlers could possibly hope to get to Dallas
and I accordingly called it off.

On June 23rd I finally got an Indian to risk his team through
the mud as far as the Halfway. Mr. McQuish had figured that we might
take it up the river road but thought it useless to do so. The
equipment is insured for $1000.00 against fire but not against water
and I felt that neither the Indian Department nor the Red Cross Society
would care to be faced with a bill of that size.

So on Tuesday evening at nine p.m., after a drive of nearly all
day through pouring rain my Indian teammate and I reached the Halfway
both soaked to the skin but our equipment dry, as we had big tarpaulins
over it.

On Wednesday I set up my equipment in Dr. Bird's office, the
resident doctor at Halfway and on Thursday I inspected the Peguis
reserve schools. We found 95% of the children with defective
teeth and several with external openings on their throat as a result
of acute abscesses. I do not believe this condition was all
work in outlying districts as much suffering directly caused from dental
work as exists in these two reserves. In many cases Peguis was a duplication
of Fisher River, only the rain had stopped and the roads were much better.
Here again we were overwhelmed with work and had to turn over a hundred
away. Even with this we tried hard and myself working until late in the
evening it was impossible to get anywhere nearly through in the month
allowed for work among the Indian children. Here again I had a very
worthy adult case — a halfbreed veteran of the Gordon's Highlanders in Europe,
who I was forced to turn down rather than turn away any more children.
The old gentleman was very disappointed, but some day he may be able
to get a set of teeth. The Department will help him to come to the
city but it will cost much more than it would have done if we could
have found the time to do it right on the ground, as five dollars
would have covered our expenses as far as material was concerned.

Before closing I wish to mention the case of a boy of fourteen
who had been suffering with severe toothache for several years but was
afraid to have his tooth extracted. As a result he developed an acute
alveolar abscess, the pus burrowing through and causing ulcers on his
throat. Dr. Bird and I gave him good extraction the roots end in three
days he was well on the road to recovery. This is only one case out of
five that we had during our stay. No wonder the tubercular trouble is
developing at a rapid rate amongst children living or rather existing
in these reserves when they have such septic mouths. That is a suffi-
cient load for the system to fight without the additional load of
influenza and tuberculosis following.
In conclusion I wish to thank Mr. and Mrs. McCuish for their kind hospitality at the Hartwood House. Dr. Bird and his humble assistance and Rev. Devons for his hospitality at Fisher River and all the teachers and missionaries for their kind assistance because the results could never have been accomplished without cooperation between us all, I am,

Your obedient servant,

(signed) R. H. Murdoch.

In looking over the dental supplies at the Fisher River dispensary I would recommend that a small pair of tooth forceps be supplied as all there at present are so large that when the Missionary tries to extract a tooth for a child as he has to sometimes (owing to road conditions making it impossible for Dr. Bird to come) they frequently taken two at once. Stevens and myself drove down to Fisher River Saturday June 6th while an Indian with his team came along bringing the dental equipment, personal baggage, etc. From Hodgson to Fisher River, I should judge it is nearly thirty miles. On several occasions our horses went down and it was a struggle to get them out. This was before the very heavy rains which started on the Sunday after our arrival and continued almost steadily for about eight or nine days.

The Mission and school are situated in a few acres of clearing which is higher than the surrounding country. Both the school and the Mission on the banks of the Fisher River are about four miles inland from the mouth of the river at Fisher Bay. The buildings are log and the out-buildings are log and all were supplied inside so that both missionary and teacher have comfortable living quarters. The buildings extend as far up as pallas and down to the lowlands along the Bay shore. It is indeed a pretty place in summer and a fine place for mosquitoes. Crossing the river in front of the school is a log foot bridge used by the Indian children when going to and from their day school.

Unfortunately directly the clinic started on the Tuesday came the rain so that practically all the children had wet feet. This would have made them more inclined to have acute trouble after extraction. In several cases I postponed treatment until another day when I thought it might be dry. Besides the children were somewhat adults wanting extractions and as they had been told I could not very well turn them down, in spite of the fact that our clinic was really a children's clinic. In the past Rev. Stevens has had to do a lot of extracting because very often the roads are too bad for the doctor to get down, and when the doctor did happen to be there the doctor did not show up. The Indians like a lot of other people do not believe in showing a tooth to a dentist unless it is aching.

During my stay in Fisher River it rained nearly every day. The river rose and on the fifth day of my visit the children's foot bridge was impassable. The day before the bridge went the Indian Agent Mr. McQuish who was down to pay out treaty money had a narrow escape from...

As it was he lost his blankets and everything in the rig. The treaty money was being carried over the foot bridge or it would have gone too.

Against all odds, rain and high water, I was kept more than busy during my stay in Fisher River. A tent was made of the adult work to see what the cost of the same would be. While in Fisher River I made up two places for an Indian woman who had the extractions completed over a year ago. I figured the cost of material approximately five dollars a plate. Of course, this is not the most expensive but is something that I think would do for the majority of treaty cases. For the children some two hundred extractions were completed. About the same number of extractions for children and adults. Some forty children received treatment and there are twice as many more to receive treatment at some future date if arrangements can be made.

I had intended to put a clinic on in Dallas on the way back but owing to the impassable condition of the roads I did not see how the children of the white settlers could possibly hope to get to Dallas and I accordingly called it off.

On June 23rd I finally got an Indian to risk his team through the mud as far as the Halfway. Mr. Schuch had figured that we might take it up the river by boat but I thought it unwise to do so. The mileage is insured for $1000.00 against fire but not against water and I felt that neither the Indian Department nor the Red Cross Society would care to be faced with a bill of that size!

We found 95% of the children with defective teeth and several with external openings on their throats as result of acute abscesses. I do not believe we have ever seen in all my work outside of distant reserves such suffering directly caused from dental sources as in these two reserves. Even with both Dr. Bird and myself working until late in the evenings it was impossible to get anywhere nearly through in the month allowed for work among the Indian children. Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith Voucher No.237 amounting to $232.65, in favor of Dr. R. H. Murdoch, 211 McIntyre block, Winnipeg. This expenditure was in connection with the Dental Clinic held in this Agency between June 4 and July 4, 1925. In the summary to the doctor's report he states where one upper and one lower set of false teeth were furnished on Fisher River Reserve and giving the regular dental rates at $40.00. The doctor informs me that the cost of this set to the Department was $4.50. In connection with this set of teeth I wish to offer the following explanation: There are a great number of men and women in this Agency who have practically no teeth left in their head so we decided to furnish one set in Fisher River and one in Pequis. Both parties chosen were women raising young families. This was done in hopes that others on the reserves would supply themselves with teeth at their own expense. The woman picked on Pequis was found to be so loaded with poison that the doctor had not time to fit her teeth and I would recommend that this case be completed. This voucher was authorized by Department Letter 136-2-5, January 28, 1925.

TRACT FROM INSPECTOR CHRISTIANSON'S REPORT ON FISHER RIVER AGENCY, dated Dec. 24, 1925, submitted through Commissioner Graham's Office, His letter #203-9, dated Dec. 31, 1925.

FISHER RIVER SCHOOL:

This building is in good shape. The only complaint that the teacher had to make was about the heating. There are no dampers in the hot air pipes leading from the furnace, and most of the heat seems to go to the two classrooms, and in cold weather the upstairs gets so cold that the children have to sit there. The only way this could be remedied would be to place dampers in the two large pipes leading to the classrooms. After school is over in the daytime, these could be closed off and the heat diverted to the upstairs. It would be a simple matter to do this, as there is a man at Dallas, about eight miles from the reserve, who is a tinsmith and would put these dampers in at a very small cost. He was not at home when I visited there and I therefore could not get prices but I cannot see that it would cost very much. When this building was painted two years ago the front and back doors were not varnished. The teacher said that if he were supplied with the varnish he would do the work. It would take about one quart of vernish and a small brush.
Ottawa, January 25, 1926.

Sir:-

Mr. Inspector Christianson in a report on his inspection of the Fisher River Indian Day School states as follows:

"This building is in good shape. The only complaint that the teacher had to make was about the heat. There are two large pipes leading from the furnace, and most of the heat seems to go to the two classrooms, and in cold weather the upstairs gets so cold that they cannot live there. The only way this could be remedied would be to place dampers in the two large pipes leading to the classrooms. After school is over in the daytime, these could be closed off and the heat directed to the upstairs. It would be a simple matter to do this, as there is a man at Dallas, about eight miles from the reserve, who is a tinsmith and would put these dampers in for a very small cost. He lives at home when I am there and I, therefore, could not get a price, but I cannot see that it would cost very much. When this building was painted two years ago the front and back doors were not varnished. The teacher said that if he were supplied with the varnish he would do the work. It would take about one quart of varnish and a small brush."

I have to request that you will arrange, as soon as possible, to have the dampers installed in the two large pipes leading to the classroom. It is noted that the Inspector states that it would be a simple matter to have the dampers placed. You may also purchase and forward to the teacher one quart of varnish and a small brush in order that he can varnish the front and back doors. After the dampers have been installed and the varnish supplied you should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. Please give these matters your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

"At the present time the requirements are a bookcase for the senior room and a desk or table for the junior room. Mr. Tong has no bookcase in his classroom and is using a box at the present time. Mrs. Tong is using an old table made out of packing boxes for a desk, and would like to have a desk or table placed between her and Mr. Tong, but due to my attention the matter of supplying a midday meal for the children. Although I have been at the school before, this was the first time Mr. Tong has mentioned the matter to me. He claims, however, to have taken it up several times with the Agent, who evidently never brought it to your attention, as I have stated in my report. Moreover, he has mentioned the supplying of a midday meal. At the present time the children get a cup of cocoa and biscuits. The teacher points out that while some of them bring fair lunches with them, there are others who bring practically nothing, and as he puts it, probably had very little breakfast, and subsisting on a cup of cocoa and a couple of dry biscuits all day does not give them enough nourishment. Arrangements could be made to turn one of the rooms in the basement into a diningroom. The only thing that would have to be done to it would be to paint the basement floor with cement paint to keep down the dust. Cheap tables and benches could be made by the girls, and a cook would have to be supplied. It could be worked out on practically the same basis as at Fairford. It would cost about $10.00 a month for additional help. As Mr. and Mrs. Tong both teach they would have to get a woman to come in during the noon hour. There are several women around there who are capable of doing this work and, of course, bigger girls could help; the services of a woman would only be required for about two hours each day. No doubt if this meal were supplied it would be a great benefit to the children, as the Doctor also pointed out that he knew some of the children were not getting sufficient nourishment."

Under cover of a letter dated October 28th, forwarding the above report, Mr. Commissioner Graham states:

"In connection with the Fisher River Day School, I think the bookcase and desk asked for should be furnished for the classes. The suggestions with regard to fixing up a room in the basement for use as a diningroom might be followed; it would cost very little. I would also recommend that $10.00 a month be allowed as wages for an Indian woman to come in and look after the preparation of the midday meal."
Ottawa, November 12th, 1926.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Christianson and Mr. Commissioner Graham recommend the supplying of a midday meal for the children of the Fisher River Indian Day School, and the fitting up of one of the rooms in the basement as a dining room for the purpose of serving this meal.

You may, therefore, arrange to have the basement floor painted with cement paint, in order to keep down the dust. You may also purchase and supply the material required to make inexpensive tables and benches. It is thought that this work could be carried out by the older boys under the supervision of the teacher. You may also purchase a cook stove to be used for preparing the meal.

The Department will be unable, owing to lack of funds, to pay for any additional help in the preparation and serving of the meal. It is considered that Mrs. Tong, with the help of the boys, given the necessary directions, should be able to prepare and serve this meal. It is not intended that any large expense be incurred in the supplies for the meal, as it is expected the children will take their lunch with them from home. It is thought that if they were served with a plate of soup, or hot cocoa and biscuits, it would be sufficient.

When the work of fitting up the room is completed, you should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure, which it is hoped you will be able to keep down to the lowest possible point.

You may also arrange for the purchase of the cocoa and biscuits, also for a small quantity of rice and barley for soup, for the midday meal.

The Inspector has recommended that a bookcase and teacher's desk and chair be supplied for the use of the classrooms. You may place an order with the Western Seating Company, 179 Ramsay Ave., Winnipeg, for the supplying of the following equipment:

1 Teacher's Sanitary Desk, No. 121,
1 Chair, No. 150c,
1 Schoolroom Bookcase, No. 8.

When placing the order with this firm, you should give full shipping directions, obtain accounts in duplicate, and when the goods have been received, you should certify the accounts and send them to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

Re Midday Meal - Fisher River Day School.

With reference to your letter, file #136-2-5 of the 12th November, 1926, I have to advise that all necessary work in connection with converting the basement of the Fisher River Day School into a dining room was completed at the end of January, 1927. There was no expense for labour in this connection, the work of painting and whitewashing, erection of tables, benches, cupboards, etc., being carried out by Mr. Tong, the teacher, and the older boy pupils.

Sir,

Re Midday Meal,
Fisher River Day School.

I beg to recommend that an amount not exceeding the sum of $100.00 be allowed for the purpose of carrying on the supplying of the noon meal to the pupils at the Fisher River Day School for the period April 1st 1927 to March 31st, 1928.

The amount of $100.00 is arrived at by keeping of careful record of cost of meals supplied during the months of February and March, 1927. Mr. Tong keeps a record of provisions used each month and number of meals supplied each day and advises me that during the month of February the meals cost 2.99 cents per meal per pupil and during the month of March, 3.07 cents per meal per pupil, making the average for the two months 3.03 cents per meal per pupil. The number of meals supplied each day averaged 65 and there being 200 school days in the year, the total cost would be approximately $364.00 for the year.

I am attaching hereto a list of supplies giving the total amount of each commodity required for the year with the approximate cost. Meals and vegetables, with the exception of onions which do not grow successfully at Fisher River, would be purchased on the reserve. Having a market for their vegetables would be an incentive to the pupils to raise them at their own homes. The other items on the list would be purchased at competitive prices from the local stores on the Fisher River Reserve.

I am also attaching a list of utensils and other supplies required which would be sufficient for the year. May authority be granted to purchase these?

The supplying of the midday meal has brought about a considerable improvement in the pupils' health, attention to school work and general interest in the school work. I would recommend strongly that the meals be carried on under the arrangement of the past two months. They have the added beneficial effect in that they enable Mrs. Tong to give the older girls a well needed lesson in cookery. The meals are prepared by two of the older girl pupils under the supervision of Mrs. Tong and each girl takes her turn at the work of cooking the meals and washing up.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman,
Indian Agent,

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK. March 13th, 1951.

Inspector Christianson's report on Schools in
the Fisher River Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that on my last trip to the Fisher River Agency, I inspected all the schools in that Agency.

FISHER RIVER IMPROVED DAY SCHOOL.

There are two classrooms in this school; the junior room is taught by Mrs. W. G. Tong, and the senior classroom by Mr. Tong. At the time of my visit there were 60 pupils in attendance, out of an enrolment of 67. The grades range as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 19     |
| II    | 18     |
| III   | 10     |
| IV    | 10     |
| V     | 5      |
| VI    | 3      |
| VII   | 2      |

The average attendance for the year is about 57.

I spent considerable time in the classrooms, and must say that I was well impressed with the work that is carried on. The children looked well, and they were clean and tidy. Their reading was good, and, in fact, all the work carried on in the classroom is much above the average found in Indian day schools. In my opinion, Mr. Tong is one of the best teachers we have in the service. Mrs. Tong is probably not as well qualified to teach as her husband, but she has greatly improved during the last few years.

A mid-day meal is served at the school.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6233, file 511-5, part 4)
FISHER RIVER IMPROVED DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

and I was present during the time the children were having it. This is certainly a great blessing as the parents of some of these children are very hard up at times, and it is gratifying to know that the children receive at least one good meal a day.

I might say that Mr. & Mrs. Tong are very much interested in their work and the welfare of the children. They not only take an interest in them while they are in school, but continue their interest after they leave the school. I consider that they are doing all they possibly can to make good citizens of them.

There are certain matters in connection with this school, regarding recruiting for Brandon School, etc., which you instructed me to look into, and which I am dealing with in a separate letter.

The school is in a good state of repair; the exterior was painted last summer, fences, etc. repaired, and the building itself is in A1 shape. The grounds are also well cared for, trees having been planted, etc.

M. Christianson

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of a voucher which you forwarded, dated the 11th instant, in favour of W. G. Young, teacher of the Fisher River Indian Day School, to reimburse him for payments made in taking off storm windows, cleaning windows and fitting screens.

In this connection, I would point out that salary for janitor's services is allowed at this school at the rate of $5.00 per month and, also, payment for sweeper at $5.00 per month. It is considered that the work of taking off and putting on storm windows, also the cleaning of the windows of the school, should be part of the janitor's regular duties. The costs of conducting this school are rather high each year and, as our funds this year are extremely limited, it will be necessary to curtail all expenditure to the lowest possible point.

The above remarks regarding the services the janitor should perform will apply to all the day schools in your agency where accounts are forwarded for payment of work which it is thought the janitors should perform in the course of their regular duties.

The voucher which you submitted will be paid in this instance.

Dear Sir:

On a recent visit to the Fisher River school and whilst inspecting the condition of the buildings I found a very serious condition in regard to the concrete walls of the basement foundation.

The whole of the east wall of the basement is bowed in by ground pressure from two to six inches. There is a crack from top to bottom at the north-east corner of the south-west corner and the ground pressure is gradually pushing the wall inward. The south wall at the east corner, for about thirty feet has dropped several inches and it also is being pressed inwardly by ground pressure.

The situation as I see it is serious, for in the matter of another year or possibly two considerable damage is liable to be done to the whole of the structure. From my examination I would lay the fault to lack of reinforcement of the concrete and a poor mixture of concrete at the extreme footings of the walls.

There are several ways that the condition might be remedied without the expense of entirely new concrete walls but whatever way you consider this repair it is going to be an expensive proposition. I will bring the condition of these walls to Inspector Hamilton's notice on his next visit to this agency.

I would also bring to your notice that the interior decoration of the classrooms in this school needs attention and the walls should be painted. If any appropriations have been set aside for the upkeep of school buildings I would ask that the matter of decoration be given attention during the vacation period, July to September.

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Lavender,
Indian Agent

The east basement wall has a bad crack reaching from one end to the other, about half way between the floor and the joists. The wall also has a bulge inward, probably 2 x 3". I do not consider this very serious and it might be remedied by placing an 8 x 8 timber under the floor joist and supporting same with heavy rests, thus somewhat relieving the pressure from the wall. The chimney of the school has a small crack from the basement to the roof. There may not be any danger from this and yet I understand the chimney is only one brick thick. It would perhaps be advisable to have bands of heavy strap iron clamped about the chimney, thus preventing any further spread. The crack could then be filled with mortar.

New swings have been erected. The work has been well done, but new rope should be provided as that now in use is badly worn out. I would recommend that rope be purchased at once in order that an accident might be avoided.
Ottawa, November 29, 1934.

Sir:

In a report regarding his recent inspection of the Fisher River Indian Day School, Inspector Hamilton writes as follows:

"The east basement wall has a bad crack reaching from one end to the other, about half way between the floor and the joists. The wall also has a bulge inward, probably 2 x 3". I do not consider this very serious, and it might be remedied by placing an 8 x 6 timber under the floor joist and supporting same with heavy joists, thus somewhat relieving the pressure from the wall. The chimney of the school has a small crack from the basement to the roof. There may not be any danger from this and yet I understand the chimney is only one brick thick. It would perhaps be advisable to have bands of heavy strap iron clamped about the chimney, thus preventing any further spread. The crack could then be filled with mortar."

Please let me know the approximate cost of making the above repairs.

Mr. Hamilton also states that rope is required for the swings. You may purchase what is necessary in this regard.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

We, the Chief and Councilors of the Fisher River Indian Reserve in the Province of Manitoba on behalf of the Chief and Councilors beg to present for your consideration of a School or a Van which we have putting through to our Indians agent several times and we never yet get no definite answer from the department we have four children that can attend school but its too far for them on account of bad roads in summer and cold in winter and stone and heavy roads. Sometimes we claim 2½ miles and four miles from the school west and we ask the department to grant us a School to build or a van as we like to see these children to learn education only we cant compel the parents to send their children to school as their too far for them.

Dear Sir;-

With reference your letter 136-2-5 and attached letter from the Chief and Councillors Fisher River Band this Agency.

Regarding the question of providing another School or a van for transportation of the children mentioned. On investigating the case at first that there are 11 children of school age which lives from 3 to 4 miles from the present improved school on the Fisher River Reserve, no doubt it would be less expense to supply a van than to send these children away to a Residential School it would entail an amount of $2.00 per teaching day for a van, but if this was done we may then have a complaint from others at North end of the Reserve as there are some who live about 2½ miles from the present school. I should think that the parents who reside so far distant from the school should resume some responsibility between themselves in getting their children to the school. The present situation does not warrant a new school as there is ample room in the present one.

Re the matter mentioned about the Rev. F. G. Stevens, as near as I can understand they wish him to leave Mr Tong alone and not interfere with him, as they are quite satisfied with his teaching. They also wish that he would not recommend any more pupils to be admitted to the Brandon Residential School, they think they can get just as good an education in the Day School on the Reserve.

I enclose herewith letter from the Chief and Councillors as requested.

Trust the above information satisfactory,

I have the honour to be, Sir.
Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Winnipeg, Man., October 16th, 1936.

FISHER RIVER IMPROVED DAY SCHOOL.

Dear Sir:

The Senior Room, which was inspected on September 28th, remains in charge of Mr. W.G. Tong.

The material for interior decoration had just arrived. The work is being done by the Indians under the supervision of Mr. Tong. The painting will greatly improve the light and general appearance of the two classrooms.

Mr. Tong complains that the roof still leaks around the Cupola. I would recommend that two or three gallons of tar be supplied and that the same be carefully applied to all cracks and joints.

The exterior of the building is badly in need of paint, as is also Mr. Tong's living quarters. If possible, this work should be carried out during the coming year.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, October 23, 1936.

Dear Sir:

In a recent report on his inspection of the Fisher River Indian Day School, Inspector Hamilton states that the roof around the cupola leaks. He recommends that two or three gallons of tar be supplied and that the same be carefully applied to all cracks and joints.

Please arrange to have this done at the earliest possible date.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. J. Clarke, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Rodgson, Man.

November 15th, 1938.

Dear Sir:

Re: Fisher River Indian Reserve Day School.

As per your instructions of the 26th of October I have examined the foundation of the above named school, and wish to make the following report in this connection.

The building in question is a frame structure, approximately 72' x 36' in size, with a full concrete foundation. This foundation is built partially on clay and rock strata.

The part of the building reported to be on the rock strata is in excellent shape, while that part on the clay is in very poor condition and should be reconstructed in the near future.

It is interesting to note that this foundation has been reconstructed in its entirety since the original foundation was installed in 1919. I am, however, given to understand that while the whole of the foundation was rebuilt the condition at that time was similar to the condition that exists today.

In investigating this work I examined the ground below the fracture walls to a depth of approximately four feet, and the material encountered was a heavy clay in a saturated state immediately below the floor or wall level and gradually decreasing in moisture content until at a depth of approximately 5.5 feet it was quite dry and hard. Two test holes were put down with a post hole auger, one in the entrance to the basement to the South of the building and one in the center under the basement floor in approximately the center of the floor where the failure of the walls has taken place. In the hole in the entrance we did not encounter rock, but in that it is in fairly close proximity to the well, and as the rock strata in the well is encountered at a depth of twelve feet, it is, I believe, reasonable to assume that we did not encounter rock at about the same depth. I mean of course, twelve feet from the ground surface, or approximately four feet from the present basement floor level. Rock was encountered at a depth of four feet two inches in the hole below the basement floor, and the material above the rock was almost identical to what referred to as a very plastic clay at the surface, saturated to such an extent that when the auger was being used a slight trickle of water was perceptible in the hole. Immediately above the rock strata the clay was almost dry.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Ottawa, Ontario.
In considering the failure of these walls, it would appear that the near collapse is a result of the plastic nature of the clay upon which the foundation is constructed. This clay has apparently been forced out by the pressure of the walls, with the result that the walls have settled. The settlement not being uniform has caused the walls to tip, and the action has apparently been supplemented by considerable lateral pressure on the East wall, as this wall is not only badly fractured but is also bulging considerably into the basement. Some disintegration of the concrete is noticeable, but in that the whole of the basement wall was constructed of the same materials and those parts which exist show that I would say that the disintegration is a result of excessive moisture and perhaps a very weak mix rather than faulty materials. However, before any repair work is carried out the materials to be used can be carefully tested. I am told that the field tile for the reconstruction job, carried out some years ago, was received too late to be installed. I am also advised that the original size of the trench was exceedingly wet when the concrete was poured.

Having carefully considered the above mentioned details I would suggest that the walls be reconstructed and I would recommend that the new walls be carried down to the rock strata, also that adequate drainage be provided for the ground immediately around that part of the building affected.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Fisher River Indian Day School.

As requested in your memorandum of October 26th last arrangements were made with Mr. Atkinson to make an inspection of the above school and submit a report of repairs required. A copy of a report received from Mr. Atkinson is attached.

From this report it would appear that Mr. Atkinson had made a fairly thorough examination of foundations and walls of the school. From his examination Mr. Atkinson's deduction is that the near collapse of the wall is a result of the plastic nature of the clay upon which the foundation is constructed. A further deduction which could apparently be made is that possibly a sufficiently thorough examination of the foundation upon which the walls were constructed was not made at the time of erection. It will be noted that Mr. Atkinson's recommendation is that in re-building these walls, they should be carried down to the rock strata and also that adequate drainage be provided for the ground around that part of the building affected.

In view of Mr. Atkinson's report on the present condition of the walls, it would appear that the only thing to do is to replace them and the recommendation to this effect in the attached report is therefore concurred in. The estimate of cost of work is of course based on such recommendation and as will be noted, totals slightly over $1,200.00.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

It has recently been brought to my attention that a letter has been received signed by Chief Murdoch and Councillors Joe Cochrane, E. Bowers and Joe Malett, of the Fisher River Band, in which they make the following statements:

"We again beg to request that a school be established at the west side of our reserve and that the materials for the building be hauled before the break up of winter. The west part of our reserve is the most suitable for farming and the future will take more and more of our people to take up residence there.

"Also as yet there is no yarn distributed to the children attending the Fisher River school. The teacher has advised us that he has not yet received this year's supply of yarn."

I should appreciate having your comments on the above and I may say that it was our understanding that when arrangements were made to drive the children to the Fisher River school you considered it unnecessary to erect another school on the west side of the reserve. As a result no provision has been made in our current year's appropriation for the erection of a new school on the Fisher River reserve.

I cannot find any record of our having refused to allow yarn for use at the Fisher River school.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter 136-2-5 of May 4th re a letter written to the Department by the Chief and Councillors of the Fisher River Band.

With reference to their request for a new school on the west end of their reserve. I would not be prepared to recommend this school. The van provided for the transportation of the children from this area is in my opinion sufficient for the present time. The majority of the men on this reserve are fishermen and will not be moving away from the present school to the farming area in the west end of the reserve.

The delivery of the yarn to the schools was late last season as we did not receive same from the company until Feb 15th.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Fisher River Indian Day School.

We have now received a report from Mr. Gow giving details of the work done at the above school which is covered under the following items,-

1. New concrete footing at N.E. and S.E. corners of the school where the old footing needed replacing.

2. Complete new foundation wall east end of school, 24 feet of the north wall extending from N.E. corner and 30 feet of the south wall extending from the S.E. corner. This concrete wall 12" thick, was reinforced by 3 1/2" rods placed at the bottom of the wall and in addition the corners were reinforced from top to bottom at intervals.

3. A 4" tile drain was placed on the footing around the entire wall of the school and this tile drain connected by tile to the river - a distance of 160 feet.

The tile drain from school to river has a minimum cover of 6' of soil and at the river the remains of the broken concrete from old wall have been placed and this covered with brush and soil to prevent freezing up of the outlet.
4. The grade entrance to the school on the south wall was entirely rebuilt with new concrete wall and floor.

5. Concrete floor was repaired in the east end of basement and adjacent to the new wall.

6. The overflow from the soft water tanks was connected by tile under the concrete floor to the old drain in the boiler room - this is connected by an existing pipeline to the river.

7. The grade around school was levelled off with a slope away from the building and the same topped with gravel, making a clean walk around the school.

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir,

On behalf of the Fisher River Band of Indians in the Province of Manitoba, we again respectfully beg to request that a school be erected and maintained at the west of our reserve. While we appreciate having been granted conveyance for our children to the present school building, weather conditions are sometimes a serious drawback and also the fact that side roads are yet only trails, making in bad weather difficult travelling.

There are in the western portion of our Reserve sufficient children of school age. This fact, we believe warrants our request for your kind consideration of our plea for a school building in the vicinity of the homes of the children now being conveyed for considerable distances.

Signed,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant regarding transportation of children to the Fisher River School. As you are aware it is necessary to avoid all expenditures that are not vital and necessary.

Please let me know the number of children that are transported to the Fisher River School each day, together with distance from Reserve. A rough sketch of the Reserve, showing the location of the children transported and also the location of the Fisher River School, would be appreciated. Dear Sir:

With reference to the van Route to the Fisher River School, I am enclosing a sketch showing the location of the school and the homes of the children using the van.

There are 4 children at J.A. Murdoch's, 3 at Walter Murdoch's, 1 at J. McKay's, 1 at Chas Sinclair's, 3 at Alex Hudson's, 3 at J. Keeper's, 3 at W.D. Murdoch's, 3 at Geo Sinclair's. It is difficult to state the exact mileage because the road is not straight, but each lot being 15 chains wide, Geo Sinclair's, the home nearest to the school, would be approximately two miles.

There is a school outside the reserve to the south at which the children in the west end of the reserve might attend. If the Dept would consider this I can make enquiries re their attending the provincial school.

Your obedient servant,

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on his inspection of the Fisher River Day School during the week of November 17, 1941.

I would recommend that four 1-quart pyrene fire extinguishers be supplied, one for the basement where there are two furnaces, one for the kitchen, one for the front hall and one for the upstairs.

One soft water tank is likely to become useless at any time. There are two tanks joined together so that the water remains at the same level in each. One tank already has about 40 holes. The teachers plugged these with sharp pointed slivers of wood. However, new holes are constantly appearing. The tanks are badly rusted and cannot be made in Winnipeg and shipped, because they will not pass through the basement door. It will therefore be necessary to ship the material and later have a man go up and put them together. If possible, this work should be done before the early spring rains.
Dear Sir:

In reporting on his recent inspection of the Fisher River Day School Inspector Hamilton writes as follows:

"One soft water tank is likely to become useless at any time. There are two tanks joined together so that the water remains at the same level in each. One tank already has about 40 holes. The teachers plugged these with sharp pointed slivers of wood. However, new holes are constantly appearing. Both tanks are badly rusted and very thin. The tanks cannot be made in Winnipeg and shipped, because they will not pass through the basement door.
