Ottawa, June 1, 1945.

Mr. F. J. Clarke, Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

With reference to requisition dated April 27, received from the teacher of the Fisher River Indian Day School, the Department approves purchase of the following articles:

- 50 yds. cotton print,
- 2 doz. spools white thread,
- 2 pkgs. needles,
- 100 lbs. sweeping compound,
- 8 galvanized furnace pipes
- 2 pipe joints.

There is also a request on the requisition for the following:

- 5 school desks EL
- 5 SL
- 10 4R small

At the same time the teacher states there are 76 school desks on hand. You did not make any comment on the request for additional desks. Are they needed to supply seating space for new pupils and is there accommodation in the classroom for them? At the present time desks are made in three sizes - large, medium and small. You should let me know the number of each size that is needed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Canada.

In reply to your letter June 1st file 136-2-5 in regard to School Desks for the Fisher River Day School, the teacher would like 5 Desks Large, 5 Desks Medium and 10 Desks Small. There is not really room for these Desks, except by over crowding. Possibly, about 5 large and 5 small desks would be enough.

There should be erected, if possible, a one room school at the West end of Fisher River Reserve, or near the West end, as there are some 17 children of school age in this vicinity. If this school were built, it would serve these children who are from 4 to 6 miles from the present Fisher River School. Some of the above children are attending, but very irregular, owing to distances and bad roads. The FAMILY ALLOWANCES ACT has played a big part in School attendance, and too, this Act allows children to attend at six, whereas prior to this, they did not start until seven years of age. We have an Indian who is willing to give a part of his land for a school location, as there is really not room for these children at the Fisher River School.

If a new school room were erected at the West end, the above desks requisitioned for the Fisher River School would probably not be needed.

F J Clarke, Indian Agent

30th October 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to requisition for authority to employ two school vans during the coming winter, for the purpose of conveying children to and from the Fisher River School, and the Peguis South School, as was done last winter.

The cost will be the same as last winter, namely $3.50 per day for each van.

A reply by return mail will be appreciated, as the roads and the weather are beginning to get bad.

P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 7 November 1946.

EXD.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent,
HODGSON, Manitoba.

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, you may arrange to drive the children to the Peguis South and Fisher River Schools for the period Dec. 1, 1946 to March 31, 1947.

It is understood that it will require two vans to do the work and that the driver will provide teams and vans and heating for the vans.

Payment will be allowed at the same rate as last year namely, $3.50 a day for each van.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I beg to advise that at the Fisher River Indian Day School, the eavestroughing and soft water tanks (2), which are of galvanized iron, in the basement, are in bad shape, and leaking. They are old. In the kitchen there is a small hand pump at the sink, which is connected with the soft water tanks, but owing to the distance between the pump and the tanks, it is impossible for the pump to draw water. The kitchen sink is not connected with the sewer, but the pipe from the sink ends above the furnaces in the basement.

To remedy these defects, it is suggested that a concrete cistern be constructed in the basement directly beneath the kitchen sink; that the eavestroughing be renewed and connected with the concrete cistern; and that the kitchen sink be connected with the sewer. To this end I have secured verbally, the following estimates of the cost:

| Description                                      | Cost   |
|--------------------------------------------------|--------|
| Construction of concrete cistern, with necessary re-inforcement. (Wylie & Compton) | $527.00 |
| Plumbing. (Mr. Jones)                            | $125.00 |
| Eavestroughing. (Kildonan Sheet Metal)           | $150.00 |

Total:- Materials & Labour. $802.00

Wylie & Compton are the firm who have been doing the building of the new Clerk's House, and other construction...
work at this agency during the past summer, and who have not yet quite completed their work. Mr. Jones is the plumber who was employed by Wylie & Compton for the plumbing work on these buildings, and the Kildonan Sheet Metal is the firm who were employed by Wylie & Compton for the furnace work and other sheet metal work on the projects.

Mrs Jean Scott, the principal teacher at the Fisher River Day School, advises that the teachers are much handicapped with the above noted facilities being unavailable to them, and she took the matter up with Mr. Inspector Hamilton, who asked me to procure the estimates set out in the foregoing.

Will you kindly advise me if the Department will approve of the necessary expenditure to carry out these repairs, and appropriate the sum of $900.00 for the purpose, as there may be some unforeseen extras in connection with the work.

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.
